question: Question 1 A settling chamber is used for the removal of discrete particulate matter from air with the following conditions: Horizontal velocity of air = [latex]0.2\ \text{m/s}[/latex] Temperature of air stream = [latex]77^\circ\text{C}[/latex] Specific gravity of particle to be removed = [latex]2.65[/latex] Chamber length = [latex]12\ \text{m}[/latex] Chamber height = [latex]2\ \text{m}[/latex] Viscosity of air at [latex]77^\circ\text{C} = 2.1 \times 10^{-5}\ \text{kg/m?s}[/latex] Acceleration due to gravity, [latex]g = 9.81\ \text{m/s}^2[/latex] Density of air at [latex]77^\circ\text{C} = 1.0\ \text{kg/m}^3[/latex] Assume the density of water as [latex]1000\ \text{kg/m}^3[/latex] and that laminar condition exists in the chamber. The minimum size of particle that will be removed with 100% efficiency in the settling chamber (in [latex]\mu m[/latex]) is ______ (round off to one decimal place).
solution:
To find the minimum size of the particle removed with 100% efficiency, we equate the settling velocity of the particle to the vertical distance the particle must settle during the residence time in the chamber.

Residence time in the chamber is: [latex] t = \frac{\text{length of chamber}}{\text{horizontal velocity}} = \frac{12}{0.2} = 60\ \text{seconds} [/latex] So, for 100% removal, the particle must fall the height of the chamber in 60 seconds: [latex] v_s = \frac{\text{height}}{t} = \frac{2}{60} = 0.0333\ \text{m/s} [/latex] Using Stokes' Law (valid under laminar conditions): [latex] v_s = \frac{g d^2 (\rho_p - \rho_f)}{18 \mu} [/latex] Where:
[latex] d = \text{diameter of particle (in m)} [/latex] [latex] \rho_p = \text{density of particle} = 2.65 \times 1000 = 2650\ \text{kg/m}^3 [/latex] [latex] \rho_f = \text{density of air} = 1.0\ \text{kg/m}^3 [/latex] [latex] \mu = \text{viscosity of air} = 2.1 \times 10^{-5}\ \text{kg/m?s} [/latex] Now solve for [latex] d [/latex]: [latex] 0.0333 = \frac{9.81 \cdot d^2 (2650 - 1)}{18 \cdot 2.1 \times 10^{-5}} [/latex] [latex] 0.0333 = \frac{9.81 \cdot d^2 \cdot 2649}{3.78 \times 10^{-4}} [/latex] [latex] d^2 = \frac{0.0333 \cdot 3.78 \times 10^{-4}}{9.81 \cdot 2649} [/latex] [latex] d^2 \approx \frac{1.25874 \times 10^{-5}}{25983.69} \approx 4.843 \times 10^{-10} [/latex] [latex] d \approx \sqrt{4.843 \times 10^{-10}} \approx 2.2 \times 10^{-5}\ \text{m} [/latex] Convert to micrometers: [latex] d = 2.2 \times 10^{-5} \times 10^6 = 22.0\ \mu m [/latex]

question:
Question 2 A community generates 1 million litres/day (MLD) of wastewater. This wastewater is treated using an activated sludge process (ASP). The working volume of the aeration tank of the ASP is [latex]250\ \text{m}^3[/latex], and the biomass concentration in the tank is [latex]3000\ \text{mg/L}[/latex].
Analysis results showed that a biomass concentration of [latex]10\ \text{mg/L}[/latex] is present in the treated effluent from the secondary sedimentation tank of the ASP.
Sludge wastage from the system is at a rate of [latex]5000\ \text{L/day}[/latex] with a biomass concentration of [latex]10000\ \text{mg/L}[/latex].
The system is in steady-state condition. The biological sludge residence time (BSRT) of the system (in days) is ______ (round off to one decimal place).
solution: BSRT (also called Solids Retention Time, SRT) is given by: [latex]\text{BSRT} = \frac{\text{Mass of biomass in aeration tank}}{\text{Mass of biomass leaving the system per day}}[/latex] Step 1: Biomass in aeration tank Volume = [latex]250\ \text{m}^3 = 250 \times 1000 = 250000\ \text{L}[/latex] Biomass concentration = [latex]3000\ \text{mg/L}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \text{Mass} = 250000 \times 3000 = 750 \times 10^6\ \text{mg} = 750\ \text{kg}[/latex] Step 2: Biomass leaving the system per day Treated effluent flow = [latex]1\ \text{MLD} = 10^6\ \text{L/day}[/latex], biomass = [latex]10\ \text{mg/L}[/latex] [latex]10 \times 10^6 = 10^7\ \text{mg/day} = 10\ \text{kg/day}[/latex] Sludge wastage = [latex]5000\ \text{L/day}[/latex], biomass = [latex]10000\ \text{mg/L}[/latex] [latex]5000 \times 10000 = 5 \times 10^7\ \text{mg/day} = 50\ \text{kg/day}[/latex] Total biomass leaving per day = [latex]10 + 50 = 60\ \text{kg/day}[/latex] Step 3: BSRT calculation [latex]\text{BSRT} = \frac{750}{60} = \boxed{12.5\ \text{days}}[/latex]

question: Question 3 The analyses results of a water sample are given below. The non-carbonate hardness of the water (in mg/L) as [latex]\text{CaCO}_3[/latex] is ______ (in integer). [latex]\text{Ca}^{2+} = 150\ \text{mg/L as CaCO}_3[/latex] [latex]\text{Mg}^{2+} = 40\ \text{mg/L as CaCO}_3[/latex] [latex]\text{Fe}^{2+} = 10\ \text{mg/L as CaCO}_3[/latex] [latex]\text{Na}^{+} = 50\ \text{mg/L as CaCO}_3[/latex] [latex]\text{K}^{+} = 10\ \text{mg/L as CaCO}_3[/latex] [latex]\text{CO}_3^{2-} = 120\ \text{mg/L as CaCO}_3[/latex] [latex]\text{HCO}_3^{-} = 30\ \text{mg/L as CaCO}_3[/latex] [latex]\text{Cl}^{-} = 50\ \text{mg/L as CaCO}_3[/latex]; Other anions were not analysed.
solution: Step 1: Total hardness is caused by multivalent cations: [latex]\text{Ca}^{2+}, \text{Mg}^{2+}, \text{Fe}^{2+}[/latex] [latex]\text{Total hardness} = 150 + 40 + 10 = 200\ \text{mg/L as CaCO}_3[/latex] Step 2: Alkalinity is contributed by [latex]\text{HCO}_3^{-}[/latex] only (because [latex]\text{CO}_3^{2-}[/latex] and [latex]\text{OH}^{-}[/latex] typically don't coexist with [latex]\text{HCO}_3^{-}[/latex] in natural water ? and presence of only 30 mg/L [latex]\text{HCO}_3^{-}[/latex] means only bicarbonate is considered). [latex]\text{Alkalinity} = 30\ \text{mg/L as CaCO}_3[/latex] Step 3: Carbonate hardness = [latex]\min(\text{Total hardness}, \text{Alkalinity})[/latex] [latex]\text{Carbonate hardness} = \min(200,\ 30) = 30\ \text{mg/L as CaCO}_3[/latex] Step 4: Non-carbonate hardness = [latex]\text{Total hardness} - \text{Carbonate hardness}[/latex] [latex]\text{Non-carbonate hardness} = 200 - 30 = \boxed{170\ \text{mg/L as CaCO}_3}[/latex] However, if we consider the total alkalinity as [latex]\text{CO}_3^{2-} + \text{HCO}_3^{-} = 120 + 30 = 150[/latex], then: [latex]\text{Alkalinity} = 150\ \text{mg/L as CaCO}_3[/latex] [latex]\text{Carbonate hardness} = \min(200,\ 150) = 150[/latex] [latex]\text{Non-carbonate hardness} = 200 - 150 = \boxed{50\ \text{mg/L as CaCO}_3}[/latex]

question:
Question 4 A 60 cm diameter well completely penetrates a confined aquifer of permeability [latex] 5 \times 10^{-4} , \text{m/s} [/latex]. The length of the strainer (spanning the entire thickness of the aquifer) is 10 m. The drawdown at the well under steady state pumping is 1.0 m.
Assume that the radius of influence for this pumping is 300 m. The discharge from the well (in litres per minute) is ______ (round off to the nearest integer).
solution: Use Thiem's equation for a confined aquifer: [latex] Q = \frac{2 \pi k b (H - h)}{\ln(R / r)} [/latex] Where: [latex] k = 5 \times 10^{-4} , \text{m/s} [/latex] (permeability) [latex] b = 10 , \text{m} [/latex] (thickness of aquifer) [latex] H - h = 1.0 , \text{m} [/latex] (drawdown) [latex] R = 300 , \text{m} [/latex] (radius of influence) [latex] r = \frac{60}{2 \times 100} = 0.30 , \text{m} [/latex] (radius of well) Substituting the values: [latex] Q = \frac{2 \pi (5 \times 10^{-4}) (10)(1)}{\ln(300 / 0.30)} = \frac{2 \pi (5 \times 10^{-3})}{\ln(1000)} [/latex] [latex] Q = \frac{0.0314}{6.9078} \approx 0.00455 , \text{m}^3/\text{s} [/latex] Convert to litres per minute: [latex] Q = 0.00455 \times 1000 \times 60 = 273 , \text{litres/minute} [/latex]

question: Question 5 A compound has a general formula [latex] \text{C}_a\text{H}_b\text{O}_c\text{N}_d [/latex] and molecular weight 187. A 935 mg/l solution of the compound is prepared in distilled deionized water. The Total Organic Carbon (TOC) is measured as 360 mg/l (as C). The Chemical Oxygen Demand (COD) and the Total Kjeldahl Nitrogen (TKN) are determined as 600 mg/l (as [latex] \text{O}_2 [/latex]) and 140 mg/l (as N), respectively (as per the chemical equation given below). Which of the following options is/are CORRECT? [latex] \text{C}_a\text{H}_b\text{O}_c\text{N}_d + \frac{4a + b - 2c - 3d}{4} , \text{O}_2 \rightarrow a , \text{CO}_2 + \frac{b - 3d}{2} , \text{H}_2\text{O} + d , \text{NH}_3 [/latex] Atomic weight: C(12), H(1), O(16), N(14)
solution:
Given: molecular weight of [latex]\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{a}} \mathrm{H}_{\mathrm{b}} \mathrm{O}_{\mathrm{c}} \mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{d}}=187 \mathrm{gm}[/latex]
Solution of compound in distilled water [latex]=935 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{t}[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{TOC} & =360 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{lt}(\text { as } \mathrm{C}) \\
\mathrm{COD} & =600 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{tt}\left(\text { as } \mathrm{O}_2\right) \\
\mathrm{TKN} & =140 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{lt}(\mathrm{As} \mathrm{~N})
\end{aligned}
[/latex] [latex]
\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{a}} \mathrm{H}_{\mathrm{b}} \mathrm{O}_{\mathrm{c}} \mathrm{~N}_{\mathrm{d}}+\frac{(4 \mathrm{a}+\mathrm{b}-2 \mathrm{c}-3 \mathrm{~d})}{4} \mathrm{O}_2 \rightarrow \mathrm{aCO}_2+\frac{\mathrm{b}-3 \mathrm{~d}}{2} \mathrm{H}_2 \mathrm{O}+\mathrm{dNH}_3
[/latex] Now, [latex]
d=\frac{\left(\frac{140}{935} \times 187\right)}{\text { Atomic weight of } \mathrm{N}}=\frac{\frac{140}{935} \times 187}{14}=2
[/latex] [latex]
a=\frac{\frac{360}{935} \times 187}{12}=6
[/latex] Now, [latex]\quad \frac{4 a+b-2 c-3 d}{4}=\frac{\left(\frac{660 \times 187}{935}\right)}{\text { Atomic weight of } \mathrm{O}_2}=\frac{\left(\frac{600 \times 187}{935}\right)}{32}[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\frac{4 \times 6+b-2 c-3 \times 2}{4} & =3.75 \\
b-2 c & =-3   \;\;\;\; (i)
\end{aligned}
[/latex] Now,
Molecular water of compound [latex]\left(\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{a}} \mathrm{H}_{\mathrm{b}} \mathrm{O}_{\mathrm{c}} \mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{d}}\right)=187[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& 12 a+b \times 1+16 c+14 d=187 \\
& 12 \times 6+b+16 c+14 \times 2=187
\end{aligned}
[/latex] [latex]
b+16 c=87   \;\;\;\; (ii)
[/latex] On solving equation (i) and (ii), we get [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{b}=7 \\
& \mathrm{c}=5
\end{aligned}
[/latex] Hence, [latex]a=6, b=7, c=5, d=2[/latex]
Correct options are (A), (B) and (C).

question: Question 6 Free residual chlorine concentration in water was measured to be [latex]2 mg/l[/latex] (as [latex]Cl_2[/latex]). The pH of water is 8.5. By using the chemical equation given below, the [latex]HOCl[/latex] concentration (in [latex]\mu moles/l[/latex]) in water is ________________ (round off to one decimal place). [latex]HOCl \rightleftharpoons H^+ + OCl^- \quad \text{p}K = 7.50[/latex] Atomic weight: [latex]Cl = 35.5[/latex]
solution: Given: Chlorine concentration = 2 mg/l (as [latex]Cl_2[/latex]) pH = 8.5 pK = 7.5 Molecular weight of [latex]Cl_2 = 71[/latex] g/mol Step 1: Convert to molar concentration [latex]\text{Moles of } Cl_2 = \frac{2}{71 \times 10^3} = 2.82 \times 10^{-5} \ \text{mol/L}[/latex] Each mole of [latex]Cl_2[/latex] gives 2 moles of total chlorine species ( [latex]HOCl[/latex] and [latex]OCl^-[/latex]): [latex][HOCl] + [OCl^-] = 2 \times 2.82 \times 10^{-5} = 5.63 \times 10^{-5} \ \text{mol/L}[/latex] Step 2: Use Henderson-Hasselbalch equation [latex]\text{pH} = \text{p}K + \log_{10} \left( \frac{[OCl^-]}{[HOCl]} \right)[/latex] [latex]8.5 = 7.5 + \log_{10} \left( \frac{[OCl^-]}{[HOCl]} \right)[/latex] [latex]\frac{[OCl^-]}{[HOCl]} = 10[/latex] Let [latex][HOCl] = x[/latex], then [latex][OCl^-] = 10x[/latex] [latex]x + 10x = 5.63 \times 10^{-5} \Rightarrow 11x = 5.63 \times 10^{-5}[/latex] [latex]x = \frac{5.63 \times 10^{-5}}{11} = 5.12 \times 10^{-6} \ \text{mol/L}[/latex] Step 3: Convert to umol/L [latex][HOCl] = 5.12 \times 10^{-6} \ \text{mol/L} = 5.12 \ \text{umol/L}[/latex] But since the concentration was given as [latex]Cl_2[/latex], we adjust for only 1 mole of chlorine contributing to HOCl: [latex][HOCl] = \frac{2}{71} \times 10^6 \times \frac{1}{11} = 2.56 \ \text{umol/L}[/latex] Final Answer: [latex]\boxed{2.6 \ \text{umol/L}}[/latex]

question: Question 7 Identify the treatment technology/technologies NOT recommended for highly biodegradable organic solid wastes.
solution: Highly biodegradable organic solid wastes are best treated using biological processes such as: - Anaerobic digestion: Produces biogas and digestate. - Composting: Produces stable compost useful as soil conditioner. - Biohydrogenation: Can be used as a bioenergy process. Open dumping , however, is not a recommended method because it causes: - Environmental pollution - Spread of diseases - Groundwater contamination Correct answer: (D) Open dumping

question: Question 8 The bacteria mainly responsible for crown corrosion in a sewer is ______.
solution: Crown corrosion in sewers is primarily caused by the presence of hydrogen sulfide (H 2 S) in the sewer gases. This gas is produced by the action of sulphur-reducing bacteria, which thrive in anaerobic conditions commonly found in sewers. These bacteria reduce sulphates to hydrogen sulfide, leading to corrosion of the crown of the sewer. Thus, the correct answer is (C) Sulphur reducing bacteria

question: Question 9 Organic fraction of municipal solid waste (OFMSW) with bulk density of [latex]315 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] and water content of [latex]30 \%[/latex] is mixed with municipal sludge of bulk density [latex]700 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] and water content of [latex]70 \%[/latex], such that the water content of the mixture is [latex]40 \%[/latex]. The amount (in kg ) of sludge to be mixed per kg of OFMSW (rounded off to 2 decimal places) and the density of the mixture (in [latex]\mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] ) (rounded off to the nearest integer) are calculated. Which of the following options is/are true:
solution: We are given: OFMSW bulk density = [latex]315\ \text{kg/m}^3[/latex], water content = [latex]30%[/latex] Sludge bulk density = [latex]700\ \text{kg/m}^3[/latex], water content = [latex]70%[/latex] Final mixture water content = [latex]40%[/latex] Let [latex]1\ \text{kg}[/latex] of OFMSW be mixed with [latex]x\ \text{kg}[/latex] of sludge Step 1: Mass of water and solids in OFMSW Water in OFMSW = [latex]1 \times 0.30 = 0.30\ \text{kg}[/latex] Solids in OFMSW = [latex]1 - 0.30 = 0.70\ \text{kg}[/latex] Step 2: Mass of water and solids in sludge Water in sludge = [latex]x \times 0.70 = 0.70x\ \text{kg}[/latex] Solids in sludge = [latex]x - 0.70x = 0.30x\ \text{kg}[/latex] Step 3: Total water and solids in the mixture Total water = [latex]0.30 + 0.70x[/latex] Total solids = [latex]0.70 + 0.30x[/latex] Total mass = [latex]1 + x[/latex] Water content of mixture = [latex]\frac{0.30 + 0.70x}{1 + x} = 0.40[/latex] Step 4: Solve for x [latex]\frac{0.30 + 0.70x}{1 + x} = 0.40[/latex] [latex]0.30 + 0.70x = 0.40(1 + x)[/latex] [latex]0.30 + 0.70x = 0.40 + 0.40x[/latex] [latex]0.30x = 0.10[/latex] [latex]x = \frac{0.10}{0.30} = 0.33[/latex] Step 5: Density of mixture Total mass = [latex]1 + 0.33 = 1.33\ \text{kg}[/latex] Volume of OFMSW = [latex]\frac{1}{315} = 0.00317\ \text{m}^3[/latex] Volume of sludge = [latex]\frac{0.33}{700} = 0.0004714\ \text{m}^3[/latex] Total volume = [latex]0.00317 + 0.0004714 = 0.0036414\ \text{m}^3[/latex] Mixture density = [latex]\frac{1.33}{0.0036414} \approx 365\ \text{kg/m}^3[/latex]

options.A: 0.33 kg of sludge added per kg of OFMSW
options.C: 0.66 kg of sludge added per kg of OFMSW

question: Question 10 A facultative pond system is employed for wastewater treatment. Which of the following statements is/are true:
solution: (A) The dissolved oxygen concentration will be high during daytime compared to night-time Reason: In a facultative pond, algae perform photosynthesis during the daytime, producing oxygen: [latex]\text{CO}_2 + \text{H}_2\text{O} \xrightarrow{\text{light}} \text{O}_2 + \text{Carbohydrates}[/latex] Thus, dissolved oxygen (DO) increases during daytime. At night, photosynthesis stops and only respiration occurs, consuming oxygen, which reduces DO levels. (B) The pH will be high during daytime compared to night-time Reason: During photosynthesis, algae consume [latex]\text{CO}_2[/latex], which reduces carbonic acid in water and increases pH. At night, [latex]\text{CO}_2[/latex] is released during respiration, forming carbonic acid and lowering pH. (C) The dissolved oxygen concentration will be low during daytime compared to night-time This is incorrect. DO is higher during the day due to photosynthesis and lower at night due to respiration. (D) The pH will be low during daytime compared to night-time This is incorrect. pH is higher during the day due to [latex]\text{CO}_2[/latex] consumption and lower at night due to [latex]\text{CO}_2[/latex] production. Correct options: (A) and (B)

options.A: The dissolved oxygen concentration will be high during daytime compared to nighttime
options.B: The pH will be high during daytime compared to night-time
options.C: The dissolved oxygen concentration will be low during daytime compared to nighttime
options.D: The pH will be low during daytime compared to night-time

question:
Question 11 [latex] \mathrm{MgCl}_{2}[/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{CaSO}_{4}[/latex] salts are added to 1 litre of distilled deionized water and mixed until completely dissolved. Total Dissolved Solids (TDS) concentration is [latex]500 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{l}[/latex], and Total Hardness (TH) is [latex]400 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{l}[/latex] (as [latex]\mathrm{CaCO}_{3}[/latex] ). The amounts of [latex]\mathrm{MgCl}_{2}[/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{CaSO}_{4}[/latex] added are calculated (rounded off to the nearest integer). Which of the following options is/are true: 
Atomic weights: [latex]\mathrm{Ca}(40), \mathrm{Mg}(24), \mathrm{S}(32), \mathrm{O}(16), \mathrm{Cl}(35.5), \mathrm{C}(12)[/latex]
solution: We are given: TDS = 500 mg/L TH = 400 mg/L (as CaCO3) Volume = 1 L Only two salts: [latex]\text{MgCl}_2[/latex] and [latex]\text{CaSO}_4[/latex] Molecular weight of [latex]\text{MgCl}_2[/latex] = [latex]24 + (35.5 \times 2) = 95\ \text{g/mol}[/latex] Molecular weight of [latex]\text{CaSO}_4[/latex] = [latex]40 + 32 + (16 \times 4) = 136\ \text{g/mol}[/latex] Equivalent weight of [latex]\text{Mg}^{2+}[/latex] = [latex]\frac{24}{2} = 12[/latex] Equivalent weight of [latex]\text{Ca}^{2+}[/latex] = [latex]\frac{40}{2} = 20[/latex] Let x = mg of [latex]\text{MgCl}_2[/latex] Let y = mg of [latex]\text{CaSO}_4[/latex] TDS equation: [latex]x + y = 500[/latex] TH from [latex]\text{MgCl}_2[/latex] = [latex]\left( \frac{24}{95}x \right) \times \frac{50}{12} = \frac{100x}{95}[/latex] TH from [latex]\text{CaSO}_4[/latex] = [latex]\left( \frac{40}{136}y \right) \times \frac{50}{20} = \frac{100y}{136}[/latex] Total TH = [latex]\frac{100x}{95} + \frac{100y}{136} = 400[/latex] Divide by 100: [latex]\frac{x}{0.95} + \frac{y}{1.36} = 4 \quad \text{(1)}[/latex] [latex]x + y = 500 \quad \text{(2)}[/latex] From (2): [latex]y = 500 - x[/latex] Substitute into (1): [latex]\frac{x}{0.95} + \frac{500 - x}{1.36} = 4[/latex] Try x = 103, y = 397 Check TDS: 103 + 397 = 500 Mg hardness: [latex]\frac{24}{95} \times 103 \times \frac{50}{12} \approx 108.7[/latex] Ca hardness: [latex]\frac{40}{136} \times 397 \times \frac{50}{20} \approx 291.3[/latex] Total hardness = 400 Final Answer: (C) Amount of [latex]\text{MgCl}_2[/latex] added is 103 mg (D) Amount of [latex]\text{CaSO}_4[/latex] added is 397 mg

question: Question 12 Aeration is employed as a treatment option for the removal of several pollutants from contaminated water. Identify the pollutant(s), where aeration is employed as a part of their removal:
solution: Aeration is a process where air is introduced into water to allow oxidation reactions to occur. It is commonly used to oxidize soluble iron and manganese into insoluble forms, which can then be removed by filtration. Let?s analyze the options: (A) Iron - Aeration oxidizes [latex] \text{Fe}^{2+} \rightarrow \text{Fe}^{3+} [/latex], which precipitates as [latex] \text{Fe(OH)}_3 [/latex]. (B) Cadmium - Not removed by aeration; it requires chemical precipitation or adsorption. (C) Manganese - Aeration helps oxidize [latex] \text{Mn}^{2+} \rightarrow \text{MnO}_2 [/latex] under suitable pH conditions. (D) Zinc - Not removed by aeration alone; other treatments are required. Correct answer: (A) and (C)

question: Question 13 The Surface Overflow Rate (SOR) in a rectangular sedimentation tank is [latex]45 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{d}[/latex]. Minimum diameters of spherical inorganic and organic particles expected to be completely removed in this tank are calculated. Assume that Stoke's law is applicable. Which of the following options is/are correct:
solution:
Given: Surface Overflow Rate (SOR) = [latex] 45 \, 	ext{m}^3/	ext{m}^2/	ext{day} =  rac{45}{86400} \, 	ext{m/s} \approx 5.208 	imes 10^{-4} \, 	ext{m/s} [/latex] Specific gravity of inorganic particles [latex] (G_{in}) = 2.65 [/latex] Specific gravity of organic particles [latex] (G_{org}) = 1.20 [/latex] Acceleration due to gravity [latex] g = 9.81 \, 	ext{m/s}^2 [/latex] Kinematic viscosity [latex] 
u = 1 	imes 10^{-6} \, 	ext{m}^2/	ext{s} [/latex] Using Stoke?s Law for settling velocity: [latex] V_s =  rac{g (G - 1) d^2}{18 
u} [/latex] Setting [latex] V_s = 	ext{SOR} = 5.208 	imes 10^{-4} \, 	ext{m/s} [/latex] Solving for [latex] d [/latex]: [latex] d = \sqrt{  rac{18 
u V_s}{g (G - 1)} } [/latex] For inorganic particles (G = 2.65): [latex] d = \sqrt{  rac{18 	imes 1 	imes 10^{-6} 	imes 5.208 	imes 10^{-4}}{9.81 	imes (2.65 - 1)} } [/latex] [latex] d \approx \sqrt{  rac{9.3744 	imes 10^{-9}}{16.0665} } \approx \sqrt{5.83 	imes 10^{-10}} \approx 2.414 	imes 10^{-5} \, 	ext{m} = 24.14 \, \mu	ext{m} [/latex] For organic particles (G = 1.20): [latex] d = \sqrt{  rac{18 	imes 1 	imes 10^{-6} 	imes 5.208 	imes 10^{-4}}{9.81 	imes (1.20 - 1)} } [/latex] [latex] d \approx \sqrt{  rac{9.3744 	imes 10^{-9}}{1.962} } \approx \sqrt{4.78 	imes 10^{-9}} \approx 6.91 	imes 10^{-5} \, 	ext{m} = 69.1 \, \mu	ext{m} [/latex] Correct options: (A) Minimum diameter of inorganic particles is 24 ?m (B) Minimum diameter of organic particles is 69 ?m

options.A: Minimum diameter of inorganic particles is [latex]24 \mu \mathrm{~m}[/latex]
options.B: Minimum diameter of organic particles is [latex]69 \mu \mathrm{~m}[/latex]

question: Question 14 A hydrocarbon [latex]\left(\mathrm{C}_{n} \mathrm{H}_{m}\right)[/latex] is burnt in air [latex]\left(\mathrm{O}_{2}+3.78 \mathrm{~N}_{2}\right)[/latex]. The stoichiometric fuel to air mass ratio for this process is Note: Atomic Weight: C(12), H(1) Effective Molecular Weight: Air(28.8) Ignore any conversion of [latex]N_2[/latex] in air to the oxides of nitrogen [latex]\left(\mathrm{NO}_{x}\right)[/latex]
solution: [latex]\text{Given hydrocarbon: } \text{C}_n\text{H}_m[/latex] [latex]\text{Air composition: O}_2 + 3.78 \text{N}_2[/latex] [latex]\text{Molecular weight of air} = 28.8[/latex] [latex]\text{Balanced reaction:}[/latex] [latex]\text{C}_n\text{H}_m + \left(n + \frac{m}{4}\right)\text{O}_2 + 3.78\left(n + \frac{m}{4}\right)\text{N}_2 \rightarrow \cdots[/latex] **Mass of fuel per mole:** [latex]= 12n + m[/latex] **Mass of air required per mole of fuel:** [latex]= \left(n + \frac{m}{4}\right) \times 4.78 \times 28.8 = (4n + m) \times 0.0291^{-1}[/latex] **Fuel-to-air mass ratio:** [latex]= \frac{12n + m}{(4n + m) \times \frac{1}{0.0291}} = 0.0291 \cdot \frac{12n + m}{4n + m}[/latex] [latex]\boxed{\text{Stoichiometric fuel-to-air mass ratio} = 0.0291 \cdot \frac{12n + m}{4n + m}}[/latex]

question: Question 15 Fecal Coliform (FC) concentration in river water was measured as [latex]10780 \mathrm{cfu} / 100 \mathrm{ml}[/latex]. The FC concentration after the conventional water treatment, but before chlorination, was measured as [latex]23 \mathrm{cfu} / 100 \mathrm{ml}[/latex]. The 'Log Kill' (inactivation) of FC due to the conventional water treatment is closest to
solution: [latex]\text{Initial FC concentration} = 10780 \ \text{cfu/100 ml}[/latex] [latex]\text{Final FC concentration (after treatment)} = 23 \ \text{cfu/100 ml}[/latex] [latex]\text{Log Kill} = \log_{10} \left( \frac{\text{Initial concentration}}{\text{Final concentration}} \right)[/latex] [latex]\quad = \log_{10} \left( \frac{10780}{23} \right)[/latex] [latex]\quad = \log_{10} (468.7)[/latex] [latex]\quad \approx 2.67[/latex]

question: Question 16 An organic waste is represented as [latex] \mathrm{C}_{240} \mathrm{O}_{200} \mathrm{H}_{180} \mathrm{~N}_{5} \mathrm{~S} [/latex] (Atomic weights: S-32, H-1, C-12, O-16, N-14) Assume complete conversion of [latex] \mathrm{S} [/latex] to [latex] \mathrm{SO}_{2} [/latex] while burning. [latex] \mathrm{SO}_{2} [/latex] generated (in grams) per [latex] \mathrm{kg} [/latex] of this waste is _____ (rounded off to 1 decimal place).
solution: Organic waste [latex] =\mathrm{C}_{240} \mathrm{O}_{200} \mathrm{H}_{180} \mathrm{~N}_{5} \mathrm{~S} [/latex] Weight of organic waste [latex] =1 \mathrm{~kg} [/latex] Burning of organic waste converts sulphur into sulphur dioxide as follows: [latex] \mathrm{C}_{240} \mathrm{O}_{200} \mathrm{H}_{180} \mathrm{~N}_{5} \mathrm{~S}+\mathrm{O}_{2} \rightarrow \mathrm{xCO}_{2}+\mathrm{yH}_{2} \mathrm{O}+\mathrm{zH}_{2} \mathrm{O}+\mathrm{SO}_{2} [/latex] i.e. 6362 of organic waste produces [latex] 64 \mathrm{~g} [/latex] of sulphur dioxide. So, [latex] 1 \mathrm{~kg} [/latex] of organic waste produces [latex] \frac{64}{6362} \times 1000 \mathrm{gm} [/latex] of [latex] \mathrm{SO}_{2} [/latex] So, Amount of [latex] \mathrm{SO}_{2} [/latex] produced [latex] =10 \; \mathrm{grams} / \mathrm{kg} [/latex]

question:
Question 21 A water treatment plant treats [latex] 25 \mathrm{MLD}[/latex] water with a natural alkalinity of [latex] 4.0 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{l}[/latex] (as [latex]\mathrm{CaCO}_{3}[/latex] ). It is estimated that during coagulation of this water, [latex] 450 \mathrm{~kg} [/latex]  day of calcium bicarbonates [latex]\left(\mathrm{Ca}\left(\mathrm{HCO}_{3}\right)_{2}\right)[/latex] is required based on alum dosage. Consider the atomic weight as: [latex]\mathrm{Ca}-40, \mathrm{H}-1, \mathrm{C}-12, \mathrm{O}-16[/latex] . The quantity of pure quick lime [latex]\mathrm{CaO}[/latex] (in [latex]\mathrm{kg}[/latex] ) required for this process per day is ______
(round off to 2 decimal places)
solution:
Natural alkalinity [latex] =4 \mathrm{mg} / l [/latex] as [latex] \mathrm{CaCO}_3 [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned}
\text { Alkalinity req }= & \left(\frac{450 \times 10^3 \mathrm{~g} / \text { day }}{25 \times 10^6 \mathrm{l} / \mathrm{d} \times \text { eqwt of } \mathrm{CO}\left(\mathrm{HCO}_3\right)_2} \times \text { eqwt of } \mathrm{CaCO}_3\right) \\
& \times 10^3 \frac{\mathrm{mg}}{l} \text { asCaCO } \mathrm{CaCO}_3 \\
= & \frac{450 \times 10^3 \times 10^3}{25 \times 10^6 \times 81} \times 50 \\
= & \frac{450 \times 50}{25 \times 81}=11.11 \mathrm{mg} / l \text { as } \mathrm{CaCO}_3
\end{aligned}
 [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] Alkalinity needed to be provided through outside source [latex] =(11.11-4)=7.11 \mathrm{mg} / l [/latex] as [latex] \mathrm{CaCO}_3 [/latex] [latex] =\frac{7.11}{50} [/latex] milieq [latex] / l [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \mathrm{CaO} [/latex] required [latex] =\frac{7.11}{50} [/latex] milieq [latex] / l [/latex] [latex] =\left[\frac{7.11}{50} \times\right. [/latex] eq. wt of [latex] \left.\mathrm{CaO}\right] \frac{\mathrm{mg}}{l} [/latex] [latex] =\left[\frac{7.11}{50} \times 28\right] \frac{\mathrm{mg}}{l} \times 25 \times 10^6 l / \mathrm{d} [/latex]
[latex] =99.54 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{d} [/latex]

question: Question 22 Activated carbon is used to remove a pollution from wastewater in a mixed batch reactor, which follows first-order reaction kinetics. At a reaction rate of 0.38 /day, the time (in days) required to remove the pollutant by [latex]95 \% [/latex] is ______ (rounded off to 1 decimal place).

Question 23 For assessing the compliance with the emissions standards of incineration plants, correction needs to be applied to the measured concentrations of air pollutants. The emission standard (based on [latex] 11 \%[/latex]  Oxygen) for [latex]\mathrm{HCl}[/latex] is [latex] 50 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{Nm}^{3}[/latex] and the measured concentrations of [latex]\mathrm{HCl}[/latex] and Oxygen in flue gas are [latex] 42 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{Nm}^{3}[/latex] and [latex] 13 \%[/latex] , respectively. Assuming [latex] 21 \%[/latex]  Oxygen in air, the CORRECT statement is:
solution:
As per [latex]\mathrm{CPCB}[/latex], oxygen correction factor is calculated as shown below- [latex] 
E_{s}=\frac{\left(21-0_{s}\right) E_{m}}{21-0_{m}}[/latex] Where [latex] E_{s}=[/latex]  Calculated emission concentration in [latex]\%[/latex]  at the standard percentage oxygen concentration in % [latex] E_{m}=[/latex]  Measured emission concentration in % [latex]\mathrm{O}_{s}=[/latex]  Standard oxygen concentration in % [latex]\mathrm{O}_{m}=[/latex]  Measured oxygen concentration in % Note: This correction is done only when measured % oxygen concentration is higher than standard % oxygen (i.e. [latex] 11 \%[/latex]  ) So,
[latex] 
E_{s}=\frac{21-11}{21-13} \times 42=52.5 \mathrm{Mg} / \mathrm{Nm}^{3}[/latex] Hence, no compliance, the corrected [latex]\mathrm{HCl}[/latex] emission is greater than emission standard i.e. [latex] 50 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{Nm}^{3}[/latex].

options.A: No compliance, as the corrected [latex]\mathrm{HCl}[/latex] emission is greater than the emission standard.
options.B: Compliance is there, as the corrected [latex]\mathrm{HCl}[/latex] emission is lesser than the emission standard
options.C: Compliance is there, as there is no need to apply the correction since Oxygen is greater than [latex] 11 \%[/latex]  and [latex]\mathrm{HCl}[/latex] emission is lesser than the emission standard.
options.D: No compliance, as the Oxygen is greater than [latex] 11 \%[/latex]  in the flue gas.

Question 29 Which of the following statements is/are TRUE for the aerobic composting of sewage sludge?
solution:
A bulking agent (wood ships shredded leaves or types) is intended to support the structure of sludge by increasing its porosity to encourage effective aeration. In-vessel composting systems can be divided into plug flow and agitated bed modes. In plug flow mode, the relationship between particles in the composting mass stays the same through the process and the system operates on first-in, first-out principle. In an agitated bed system, composting material is mixed mechanically during the processing. The heat produced in aquatic composting cause any surplus moisture to be extracted as water vapour and hence no leachate is produced. Actinomycetes are aerobic, spore forming positive bacteria. These are thermophilic species and their development depends on aerobic conditions, temperature and water content. The heat produced in aerobic
composting helps support the growth of these species. Leachate can generated from vegetable wastes.

options.A: Bulking agent is added during the composting process to reduce the porosity of the solid mixture
options.B: Leachate can be generated during composting
options.C: Actinomycetes are involved in the process
options.D: In-vessel composting systems cannot be operated in the plug-flow mode

question: Question 30 In the context of water and wastewater treatments, the correct statements are:
solution: Total dissolved solids comprise of inorganic salts, principally calcium, magnesium, potassium, sodium bicarbonates, chlorides, sulfates and some small amount of organic matter that are dissolved in water. Hardness is due to presence of multivalent cations. In most cases, it is due to the presence of soluble bicarbonates, chlorides and sulfates of calcium and magnesium. Too much phosphorous can cause increased growth of algae and large aquatic plants. It can result in decreased levels of dissolved oxygen and the process is called 'Eutrophication'. Ammonia creates a large chlorine demand, as the ammonia is converted to nitrogen gas and the chlorine becomes chloride during disinfection of water by chlorination. Presence of particulate matter decreases the effectiveness of UV disinfection or chlorine disinfection by shielding the targeted microorganisms.

options.A: particulate matter may shield microorganisms during disinfection
options.C: phosphorous stimulates algal and aquatic growth
options.D: calcium and magnesium increase hardness and total dissolved solids

question:
Question 31 Match the following air pollutants with the most appropriate adverse health effects: [latex]

\begin{array}{|l|l|}
\hline 
\textbf{Air pollutant} & \textbf{Health effect to human and/or test animal} \\
\hline
\text{(P) Aromatic hydrocarbons} & \text{(I) Reduce the capability of the blood to carry oxygen} \\
\hline
\text{(Q) Carbon monoxide} & \text{(II) Bronchitis and pulmonary emphysema}\\
\hline
\text{(R) Sulfur oxides}& \text{(III) Damage of chromosomes} \\
\hline
\text{(S) Ozone} & \text{(IV) Carcinogenic effect} \\
\hline
\end{array}

[/latex]
solution: Aromatic hydrocarbons such as 3, 4benzpyrene, other polycyclic organic compounds which are originated due to incomplete combustion of hydrocarbons are considered to be carcinogenic agents. These are responsible for cancer. Sulphur dioxide [latex]\left(\mathrm{SO}_{2}\right)[/latex] : It is an irritant gas which effects mucous membrane when inhaled. It leads to bronchial spasms. Asthma patients are badly affected. Carbon Monoxide (CO) : Carbon monoxide has a strong affinity for combining with the haemoglobin of the blood to form carboxyhemoglobin, [latex]\mathrm{COHb}[/latex]. This reduces the ability of the haemoglobin to carry oxygen to the body tissues. CO has about two hundred time the affinity of oxygen for attaching itself to the haemoglobin, so that low levels of CO can still result in high levels of [latex]\mathrm{COHb}[/latex]. Carbon monoxide also affects the central nervous system. Ozone [latex]\left(\mathrm{O}_{3}\right)[/latex] can damage the tissue of the respiratory tract, causing inflammation and irritation, and result in symptoms such as coughing, chest tightness and worsening of asthma symptoms. In addition, ozone causes substantial damage to crops, forests and native plants.

\begin{array}{|l|l|}
\hline
\begin{array}{l}\text {Evaluation from} \\ \text {ground level}(\mathrm{m})\end{array} & \text{Temperature }\left({ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right) \\

5 & 14.2 \\
\hline
325 & 16.9 \\

solution: Lapse rate, [latex]\lambda=\frac{\text { Difference in Temperature }}{\text { Difference in height }}=\frac{\Delta \mathrm{T}}{\Delta \mathrm{H}}[/latex] [latex]\lambda=\frac{\Delta \mathrm{T}}{\Delta \mathrm{H}}=\frac{16.9-14.2}{325-5}[/latex] [latex]\lambda=0.0084375^{\circ} \mathrm{C} / \mathrm{m}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad \lambda=\frac{0.0084375 \times 100}{100 \mathrm{~m}}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad \lambda=\frac{0.084375^{\circ} \mathrm{C}}{100 \mathrm{~m}}=0.84^{\circ} \mathrm{C} / 100 \mathrm{~m}[/latex]

question:

question:
Question 35 The wastewater inflow to an activated sludge plant is [latex]0.5 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{s}[/latex], and the plant is to be operated with a food to microorganism ratio of [latex]0.2 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{mg}-\mathrm{d}[/latex]. The concentration of influent biodegradable organic matter of the wastewater to the plant (after primary settling) is [latex]150 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{L}[/latex], and the mixed liquor volatile suspended solids concentration to be maintained in the plant is [latex]2000 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{L}[/latex]. Assuming that complete removal of biodegradable organic matter in the
tank, the volume of aeration tank (in [latex]\mathrm{~m}^{3}[/latex]
, in integer)
required for the plant is _____.
solution:
Given, [latex]\begin{aligned} 
Q_1&=6.5 m^3/s \\
&=0.5 \times 24 \times 60 \times 60 \\
&=43200 m^3/d\\
\frac{F}{M} & =0.2 (mg/mg-d)\\
\mathrm{S}_0 & =150 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{l} \\ \mathrm{X} & =2000 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{l} \\ \because \quad \frac{F}{M} & =\frac{\mathrm{Q}_0 \mathrm{~S}_0}{\mathrm{VX}} \\ 0.2 & =\frac{43200 \times 150}{\mathrm{~V} \times 2000} \\ V & =16200 \mathrm{~m}^3\end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 37 The composition and energy content of a representative solid waste sample are given in the table. [latex]
\begin{array}{|l|l|l|}
\hline
Component & \text{Percent} & \text{Energy} \\ & \text{by mass}  & \text{content} \\ & & \text{as-discarded} \\ & &\text{basis} \\& &   (\mathbf{M J} / \mathbf{k g}) \\
\hline
Food \; waste & 20 & 4.5 \\
\hline
Paper & 45 & 16.0 \\
\hline
Cardboard & 5 & 14.0 \\
\hline
Plastics & 10 & 32.0 \\
\hline
Others & 20 & 8.0 \\
\hline
\end{array}
[/latex]
solution:
Assuming [latex]1 \mathrm{Kg}[/latex] of solid waste [latex]
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text {Component} & \text {Percent}& \text {Mas (Kg)} & \text { Energy} & \text { Energy}\\ & \text{by mass}& & \text{content} & \text{of waste (MJ)}\\

\hline
Food \; waste & 20 & 0.2 & 4.5 & 0.2 \times 4.5=0.9 \\
\hline
Paper & 45 & 0.45 & 16.0 & 0.45 \times 16=7.2 \\
\hline
Carboard & 5 & 0.05 & 14.0 & 0.05 \times 14=0.7\\
\hline
Plastics & 10 & 0.10 & 32.0 & 0.1 \times 32=32 \\
\hline
Others & 20 & 0.20 & 80 & 0.2 \times 8=1.6 \\

Question 40 Which of the following statements is/are TRUE for
the Refuse-Derived Fuel (RDF) in the context of
Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) management?
solution: (A) is false. The Higher Heating Value (HHV) of Refuse-Derived Fuel (RDF) processed from Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) is typically higher than the HHV of unprocessed MSW. This is because RDF processing removes non-combustible materials from MSW and concentrates the combustible fraction. (B) is true. RDF can be produced in various forms including pellets, fluff, and powdered form. The form of RDF depends on the specific process and intended end use. (C) is partially true. RDF processing typically removes a significant portion of the inorganic fraction of MSW, but not all of it. The remaining inorganic fraction is typically mixed with the RDF product. (D) is false. RDF can be used as a fuel in a variety of combustion systems, including those that burn oil. In fact, RDF is often used as a supplemental fuel in cement kilns and other industrial processes that also use oil as a fuel.

options.A:
Higher Heating Value (HHV) of the unprocessed
MSW is higher than the HHV of RDF processed
from the same MSW.
options.B: RDF can be made in the powdered form
options.C:
Inorganic fraction of MSW is mostly converted
to RDF.
options.D: RDF cannot be used in conjunction with oil.

The initial condition [latex]s(x, 0)[/latex] is defined by the step-function shown in the figure. Consider [latex]D = 0. 1 m^2/s,
s_0 = 5 \mu mol/m[/latex], and [latex]L = 10 m[/latex]. The steady-state concentration [latex]\tilde{S}\left ( \frac{L}{2} \right )=S\left ( \frac{L}{2},\infty  \right )[/latex], at the center [latex]x=\frac{L}{2}[/latex] of the reservoir (in [latex]\mu[/latex]mol/m) is ___________. (in integer)
solution:
From figure s(x,t) at [latex] x=0\Rightarrow s(0,t)=s_0=5[/latex] at [latex] x=0.4L\Rightarrow s(0.4L,t)=s_0=5[/latex] at [latex] x=L\Rightarrow s(L,t)=0[/latex] From [latex]x = 0\;  to \;x = 0.4 L[/latex] Concentration of pollutant [latex]5\mu \; mol/m \times (0.4 \times 10m) =20 \mu \; mol[/latex] [latex]x = 0.4L\;  to \;x =  L[/latex] Concentration of pollutant = 0 Total concentration of pollutant in 10 m [latex]=20 \mu \; mol[/latex] In infinite time this concentration will be diluted
so concentration of pollutant per m [latex]=\frac{20}{10} \mu \; mol/m=2 \mu \; mol/m[/latex] Under steady state condition, concentration of
pollutant will be uniformly distributed. Steady state concentration at [latex]x=\frac{L}{2} =2\mu \; mol/m[/latex]

question:
Question 47 In a city, the chemical formula of biodegradable fraction of municipal solid waste
(MSW) is [latex]C_{100}H_{250}O_{80}N[/latex]. The waste has to be treated by forced-aeration
composting process for which air requirement has to be estimated. Assume oxygen in air (by weight) = 23 %, and density of air = 1.3 [latex]kg/m^3[/latex].

Atomic mass: C = 12, H = 1, O = 16, N = 14. C and H are oxidized completely whereas N is converted only into [latex]NH_3[/latex] during
oxidation. For oxidative degradation of 1 tonne of the waste, the required theoretical volume
of air (in [latex]m^3/tonne[/latex]) will be (round off to the nearest integer)
solution:
[latex] C_{100}H_{250}O_{80}N+xO_2\rightarrow 100CO_2+\frac{247}{2}H_2O+NH_3[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned}
80+x \times 2&=200+\frac{247}{2}\\
x&=121.75
\end{aligned}[/latex] 1 mole of MSW required 121.75 mole of oxygen
No. of moles of MSW [latex] =\frac{1 \; ton}{(100 \times 12+250+80 \times 16+14)g}[/latex] No. of moles of O2 required
[latex] =121.75 \times \frac{1 \; tonne}{2744g}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned}
\text{wt. of }O_2&=  \frac{121.75}{2744}\times 32 \; tonne\\
\text{Mass of air }&=  \frac{1.42}{0.23}\times 10^3 Kg\\
&=6.174 \times 10^3kg\\
\text{Density of air }&=  1.3 Kg/m^3\\
\text{Volume of air }&=  \frac{6.174}{1.3}\times 10^3 m^3\\
=4749.2 m^3 &\text{per tonne of MSW}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 48 A 100 mg of [latex]HNO_3[/latex] (strong acid) is added to water, bringing the final volume to
1.0 liter. Consider the atomic weights of H, N, and O, as 1 g/mol, 14 g/mol, and
16 g/mol, respectively. The final pH of this water is
(Ignore the dissociation of water.)
solution:
[latex]HNO_3\rightarrow H^++NO_3^{-} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned}
\text{1 mole of }HNO_3&=\text{1 mole of }H^+\\
\text{No. of mole of }HNO_3&=\frac{100}{(1+14+16 \times 3)}\\
&=1.587 m\; mol\\
[H^+] \text{ in 1 lit. of water }&=1.587 m\;mol/Lit\\
&=1.587 \times 10^{-3}\;mol/Lit\\
pH&=-\log[H^+]\\
&=\log[1.587 \times 10^{-3}]\\
&=2.8
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 49 To design an optimum municipal solid waste collection route, which of the

following is/are NOT desired:
solution:
Some heuristic guidelines that should be taken
into consideration when laying out routes are as
follows : 1. Existing policies and regulations related to
such items as the point of collection and
frequency of collection must be identified. 2. Existing system characteristics such as crew
size and vehicle types must be coordinated. 3. Wherever possible, routes should be laid out
so that they begin and end near arterial
streets, using topographical and physical
barriers as route boundaries. 4. In hilly area, routes should start at the top of
the grade and proceed downhill as the vehicle
becomes loaded. 5. Routes should be laid out so that the last
container to be collected on the route is
located nearest to the disposal site. 6. Waste generated at traffic-congested locations
should be collected as early in the day as
possible. 7. Sources at which extremely large quantities
of waste are generated should be serviced
during the first part of the days. 8. Scattered pickup points (where small quantities
of solid waste are generated) that receive the
same collection frequency should, if possible,
be serviced during one trip or on the same day.

options.A: Collection vehicle should not travel twice down the same street in a day.
options.B: Waste collection on congested roads should not occur during rush hours in morning or evening.
options.C: Collection should occur in the uphill direction.
options.D: The last collection point on a route should be as close as possible to the waste disposal facility.

question: Question 60 A grit chamber of rectangular cross-section is to be designed to remove particles with diameter of 0.25 mm and specific gravity of 2.70. The terminal settling velocity of the particles is estimated as 2.5 cm/s. The chamber is having a width of 0.50 m and has to carry a peak wastewater flow of [latex]9720 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{d}[/latex] giving the depth of flow as 0.75 m. If a flow-through velocity of 0.3 m/s has to be maintained using a proportional weir at the outlet end of the chamber, the minimum length of the chamber (in m,in integer) to remove 0.25 mm particles completely is _________
solution: Minimum length of chamber [latex]\begin{aligned} L_{\min } &=V_{\text {flow }} \times t_{d} \\ V_{\text {fow }} &=0.30 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \\ t_{d} &=\frac{H}{V_{\text {settling }}}=\frac{0.75}{2.5 \times 10^{-2}}=30 \mathrm{sec} \\  L_{\text {min }} &=0.3 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{sec} \times 30 \mathrm{sec} \\ &=9 \mathrm{~m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 61 An activated sludge process (ASP) is designed for secondary treatment of [latex]7500 m^{3} / day[/latex] of municipal wastewater. After primary clarifier, the ultimate BOD of the influent, which enters into ASP reactor is 200 mg/L. Treated effluent after secondary clarifier is required to have an ultimate BOD of 20 mg/L. Mix liquor volatile suspended solids (MLVSS) concentration in the reactor and the underflow is maintained as 3000 mg/L and 12000 mg/L, respectively. The hydraulic retention time and mean cell residence time are 0.2 day and 10 days, respectively. A representative flow diagram of the ASP is shown below. The underflow volume (in [latex]m^{3} / day[/latex], round off to one decimal place) of sludge wastage is _________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given,}  \qquad X &=3000 \mathrm{mg} / l, \quad X_{\mathrm{u}}=12000 \mathrm{mg} / l \\ \text{Since} \qquad  \mathrm{HRT} &=\frac{V}{Q_{0}}\\ \Rightarrow &\text{Volume of reactor,}\\ V &=Q_{0} \times H R T \\ &=7500 \times 0.2 \mathrm{~m}^{3} \\ &=1500 \mathrm{~m}^{3} \\ &\text{Sludge age,} \\ \theta_{\mathrm{C}} &=\frac{V X}{\left(Q_{0}-Q_{w}\right) X_{e}+Q_{w} X_{u}} \qquad \left(X_{e} \simeq 0\right)\\ 10&=\frac{1500 \times 3000}{Q_{W} \times 12000}\\ Q_{w}&=37.5 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / day \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 62 A water filtration unit is made of uniform-size sand particles of 0.4 mm diameter with a shape factor of 0.84 and specific gravity of 2.55. The depth of the filter bed is 0.70 m and the porosity is 0.35. The filter bed is to be expanded to a porosity of 0.65 by hydraulic backwash. In the terminal settling velocity of sand particles during backwash is 4.5 cm/s, the required backwash velocity is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} n^{\prime} &=\text { Porosity of expanded bed } \\ n^{\prime} &=\left(\frac{V_{B}}{V_{s}}\right)^{0.22} \\ 0.65 &=\left(\frac{V_{B}}{4.5 \mathrm{~cm} / \mathrm{s}}\right)^{0.22} \\ V_{B} &=6.35 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 68 Determine the correctness or otherwise of the following Assertion [a] and the Reason [r]. Assertion [a]: One of the best ways to reduce the amount of solid wastes is to reduce the consumption of raw materials. Reason [r]: Solid wastes are seldom generated when raw materials are converted to goods for consumption.
solution: Solid waste generated by the use of raw material, processing and finished goods

options.A: Both [a] and [r] are true and [r] the correct reason for [a]
options.B: Both [a] and [r] are true but [r] is not the correct reason for [a]

question: Question 69 A secondary clarifier handles a total flow of [latex]9600 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{d}[/latex] from the aeration tank of a conventional activated-sludge treatment system. The concentration of solids in the flow from the aeration tank is 3000 mg/L. The clarifier is required to thicken the solids to 12000 mg/L, and hence it is to be designed for a solid flux of [latex]3.2 \frac{\mathrm{kg}}{\mathrm{m}^{2} \cdot \mathrm{h}}[/latex]. The surface area of the designed clarifier for thickening (in [latex]\mathrm{~m}^{2}[/latex], in integer) is _________________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q &=9600 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{d} \\ X &=3000 \mathrm{mg} / l \\ X_{u} &=12000 \mathrm{mg} / l \\ \text {Solid flux }& =3.2 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{2}-\mathrm{h}\\ \text{Surface area,}  \qquad \mathrm{A}&=\frac{\text { Total quantity of solids entering }}{\text { Solid flux }}\\ A &=\frac{9600 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{d} \times 3000 \mathrm{mg} / l}{3.2 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{m}^{2}-\mathrm{h}} \\ &=\frac{9600 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{lld} \times 3000 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{l}}{3.2 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{m}^{2}-\mathrm{h} \times 24 \mathrm{~h} / \mathrm{d}} \\ &=375 \mathrm{~m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 70 A baghouse filter has to treat [latex]12 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] of waste gas continuously. The baghouse is to be divided into 5 sections of equal cloth area such that one section can be shut down for cleaning and/or repairing, while the other 4 sections continue to operate. An air-to-cloth ratio of [latex]6.0 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{min}-\mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] cloth will provide sufficient treatment to the gas. The individual bags are of 32 cm in diameter and 5 m in length. The total number of bags (in integer) required in the baghouse is ________________
solution:
Given, discharge to be passed = [latex]12 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] Out of 5 sections, 4 will operate at a time. Each bag is Thus, surface area of each bag [latex]=\pi \times 0.32 \times 5 \mathrm{~m}^{2}=5.0265 \mathrm{~m}^{2}[/latex] Total surface area required wr.t. given discharge [latex]=\frac{12 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{s}}{6 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{min}-\mathrm{m}^{2}}=\frac{12 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{s}}{\frac{6}{60} \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{s}-\mathrm{m}^{2}}=120 \mathrm{~m}^{2}[/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex]
Working bag filters required [latex]=\frac{120 m^{2}}{5.0265 m^{2}}=[/latex] 23.87 or 24 bag filters But, since it is asked total (which includes a standby set also), then,Total no. of bag filters [latex]=24 \times \frac{5}{4}=30[/latex]

question: Question 72 A water sample is analyzed for coliform organisms by the multiple-tube fermentation method. The results of confirmed test are as follows: [latex]\begin{array}{|l|c|c|} \hline \text { Sample size (mL) } & \begin{array}{c} \text { Number of positive } \\ \text { results out of } 5 \text { tubes } \end{array} & \begin{array}{c} \text { Number of negative } \\ \text { results out } 5 \text { tubes } \end{array} \\ \hline 0.01 & 5 & 0 \\ \hline 0.001 & 3 & 2 \\ \hline 0.0001 & 1 & 4 \\ \hline \end{array}[/latex] The most probable number (MPN) of coliform organisms for the above results is to be obtained using the following MPN Index. The MPN of coliform organisms per 100 mL is
solution:
The sample size is 0.01 ml, 0.001 ml and 0.0001 ml which is 1000 times lesser than
the standard of 10 ml, 1 ml and 0.1 ml. The positive set is 5-3-1 and w.r.t. the positive combination, MPN/100 ml will be 110 x 1000 = 110000

question: Question 73 A 50 mL sample of industrial wastewater is taken into a silica crucible. The empty weight of the crucible is 54.352 g. The crucible with the sample is dried in a hot air oven at 104 [latex]^{\circ}C[/latex] till a constant weight of 55.129 g. Thereafter, the crucible with the dried sample is fired at 600 [latex]^{\circ}C[/latex] for 1 h in a muffle furnace, and the weight of the crucible along with residue is determined as 54.783 g. The concentration of total volatile solids is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V&= 50 \; ml\\ W_1&=54.352\; gm \\ W_2&=55.129 \; gm \\ W_3&=54.783 \; gm \\ &\text{Total volatile solids,} \\ &=\frac{W_2-W_3}{V} \\ &= \frac{(55.129-54.783)}{50} \times 10^6 \; mg/lit\\ &=6920\; mg/l \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 77 A sample of water contain an organic compound [latex]C_8H_{16}O_8[/latex] at a concentration of [latex]10^{-3}[/latex] mol/litre.
Given that the atomic weight of C = 12 g/mol, H = 1 g/mol, and O = 16 g/mol, the
theoretical oxygen demand of water (in g of [latex]O_2[/latex] per litre, round off to two decimal places),
is ___________
solution: [latex]C_8H_{16}O_8[/latex] of conc [latex]10^{-3}[/latex] moles/lt required [latex]O_2[/latex] (in gm/lt) [latex]C_8H_{16}O_8 +8O_2\rightarrow 8CO_2+8H_2O[/latex] 1 mole of [latex]C_8H_{16}O_8[/latex] requires 8 moles of [latex]O_2[/latex] for its decomposition [latex]\begin{aligned} 240 gm &= 128 gm\\ 10^{-3} moles&=8 \times 10^{-3}moles \\ &= 8 \times 10^{-3} \times 32\\ &= 0.256 gm/lt \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 78 A waste to energy plant burns dry solid waste of composition : Carbon = 35%, Oxygen = 26%, Hydrogen = 10%, Sulphur = 6%, Nitrogen = 3% and Inerts = 20%. Burning rate is 1000 tonnes/d. Oxygen in air by weight is 23%. Assume complete
conversion of Carbon to [latex]CO_2[/latex], Hydrogen to [latex]H_2O[/latex], Sulphur to [latex]SO_2[/latex] and Nitrogen to [latex]NO_2[/latex]. Given Atomic weighs : H=1, C=12, N=14, O=16, S=32. The stoichiometric (theoretical) amount of air (in tonnes/d, round off to the nearest integer)
required for complete burning of this waste, is __________.
solution: [latex]\underbrace{C}_{12}\underbrace{O}_{2}\rightarrow CO_2[/latex] Oxygen required for 350 tonne/day [latex]\frac{32}{12}\times 350=933.33[/latex] [latex]\underbrace{4H}_{4}+\underbrace{O_2}_{32}\rightarrow 2H_2O[/latex] Oxygen required for 100 tonne/day [latex]\frac{32}{4}\times 100=800[/latex] [latex]\underbrace{S}_{32}+\underbrace{O_2}_{32}\rightarrow SO_2[/latex] Oxygen required for 60 tonne/day [latex]\frac{32}{32}\times 60=60[/latex] [latex]\underbrace{N}_{14}+\underbrace{O}_{32}\rightarrow NO_2[/latex] Oxygen required for 30 tonne/day [latex]\frac{32}{14}\times 30=68.57[/latex] Total [latex]O_2[/latex] = 1861.9 tonne/day Available [latex]O_2[/latex] in waste = 260 tonne/day Required =1861.9-260=1601.9 tinne/day Amount of air required [latex]=\frac{1601.9}{0.23}=6964.78 \; \text{tonne/day} \simeq 6965 \; \text{tonne/day}[/latex]

question:
Question 79 The ion product of water ([latex]pK_w[/latex]) is 14. If a rain water sample has a pH of 5.6, the
concentration of [latex]OH^-[/latex] in the sample (in [latex]10^{-9}[/latex] mol/litre, round off to one decimal place),
is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} pH+pOH&=14\\ pOH&=14-5.6=8.4\\ -log[OH^-]&=8.4\\ [OH^-]&=10^{-8.4}\; moles/lt\\ &=10^{-8.4+9} \times 10^{-9}\; moles/lt\\ &=3.98 \times 10^{-9} \; moles/lt \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 80 Alkalinity of water, in equivalent/litre (eq/litre), is given by [latex]\{HCO_3^-\}+2\{CO_3^{2-}\}+\{OH^-\}-\{H^+\}[/latex] where, { } represents concentration in mol/litre. For a water sample, the concentration
of [latex]HCO_3^? = 2 \times 10^{-3}[/latex] mol/litre, [latex]CO_3^{2-} = 3.04 \times 10^{-4}[/latex] mol/litre and the pH of water = 9.0.
The atomic weights are : Ca = 40; C = 12; and O = 16. If the concentration of [latex]OH^-[/latex]
and [latex]H^+[/latex] are NEGLECTED, the alkalinity of the water sample (in mg/litre as [latex]CaCO_3[/latex]), is
solution: Alkalinity of water sample is due to presence of [latex][HCO_3^-][/latex] and [latex][HCO_3^{2-}][/latex] Total alkalinity = 1 mole of [latex][HCO_3^-][/latex] + 2 mole of [latex][HCO_3^{2-}][/latex] in terms of [latex]CaCO_3[/latex] [latex]=(2 \times 10^{-3} \times 50 +2 \times 3.04 \times 10^{-4} \times 50) \times 10^3 mg/l[/latex] [latex]=130.4 mg/l \; as \; CaCO_3[/latex]

question:
Question 81 A gas contains two types of suspended particle having average sizes of 2 [latex]\mu m[/latex] and
50 [latex]\mu m[/latex]. Amongst the options given below, the most suitable pollution control strategy
for removal of these particles is
solution:
Large size particles should be removed first, hence answer should be (A). Theoretically, gravitational settling chamber
should be able to remove particulates down to 5
or 10 [latex]\mu m[/latex], but in actual they are not practical for
removal of particles much less than 50 [latex]\mu m[/latex] in
size. Hence, gravitational settling chamber is most
suitable choice for removal of suspended particles
of size 50 [latex]\mu m[/latex]. After the removal of 50 [latex]\mu m[/latex] size particles, to
remove 2 [latex]\mu m[/latex] size particles, we use fabric bag
filter. Note: Fabric bag filter has high collection
efficiency for all particle sizes, especially for
particles smaller than 10 [latex]\mu m[/latex] in diameter.

options.A: settling chamber followed by bag filter
options.B: electrostatic precipitator followed by venturi scrubber
options.C: electrostatic precipitator followed by cyclonic separator
options.D: bag filter followed by electrostatic precipitator

question:
Question 82 The relationship between oxygen consumption and equivalent biodegradable organic
removal (i.e. BOD) in a closed container with respect to time is shown in the figure. Assume that the rate of oxygen consumption is directly proportional to the amount of
degradable organic matter and is expressed as [latex]\frac{dL_t}{dt}=-kL_t[/latex], where, [latex]L_t[/latex] (in mg/litre) is the oxygen equivalent of the organics remaining at time t and [latex]k[/latex] (in [latex]d^{-1}[/latex]) is the degradation
rate constant. [latex]L_0[/latex] is the oxygen of organic matter at time, t = 0. In the above context, the correct expression is
solution:
Given, [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{dL_t}{dt}&=-kL_t \\ \Rightarrow \; \frac{dL_t}{L_t} &=-kdt \\ \Rightarrow \; \int_{L_o}^{L_t} \frac{dL_t}{L_t} &=-k\int_{0}^{t}dt \\ \Rightarrow \; \ln \left ( \frac{L_t}{L_o} \right ) &=-kt \\ \Rightarrow \; L_t&=L_o e^{-kt} \end{aligned}[/latex] The term [latex]L_o[/latex] in the above equation represents
the total oxygen equivalent of the organics at
time [latex]t=0[/latex], while [latex]L_t[/latex] represents the amount
remaining at time [latex]t[/latex], and decays exponentially
with time. The amount of oxygen used in the consumption
of the organics, the [latex]{BOD}_t[/latex]
 can be found from the [latex]L_t[/latex] value. The difference between the value [latex]L_o[/latex] and [latex]L_t[/latex] is
the oxygen equivalent consumed, or the BOD
exerted. Mathematically [latex]{BOD}_t=(L_o-L_t)=L_o-L_oe^{-kt}=L_o(1-e^{-kt})[/latex]

question:
Question 83 A stream with a flow rate of 5 [latex]m^3/s[/latex] is having an ultimate BOD of 30 mg/litre. A wastewater
discharge of 0.20 [latex]m^3/s[/latex] having BOD5 of 500 mg/litre joins the stream at a location and
instantaneously gets mixed up completely. The cross-sectional area of the stream is
40 [latex]m^2[/latex] which remains constant. BOD exertion rate constant is 0.3 per day (logarithm base
to e). The BOD (in mg/litre round off to two decimal places) remaining at 3 km downstream
from the mixing location, is ________.
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
t &=\frac{d}{v} \\ 
 \text{where,} \;\; v&=\frac{Q_s+Q_R}{A} \\ 
 &= \frac{0.2+5}{40}=0.13 m/sec\\ 
 t&=\frac{3 \times 10^3}{0.13 \times 86400}=0.26 \;day \\ 
 BOD_5&=BOD_u(1-e^{-k\times 5}) \\ 
 BOD_u&=\frac{500}{(1-e^{-0.5 \times 5})}=643.66\; mg/l \\ 
 DO_{mix}&=\frac{Q_RBOD_u+Q_s BOD_u}{Q_s+Q_R} \\ 
 &=\frac{5 \times 30+0.2\times 643.66}{5+0.2} \\ 
 &= 53.6\; mg/l\\ 
 L_t&=L_0 e^{-k \times t} \\
&=53.6 e^{-0.3 \times 0.26}\\
&=49.57\; mg/l
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 84 A gaseous chemical has a concentration of 41.6 [latex]\mu mol/m^3[/latex] in air at 1 atm pressure and
temperature 293 K. The universal gas constant R is [latex]82.05 \times 10^{-6} (m^3 atm)/(mol K)[/latex].
Assuming that ideal gas law is valid, the concentration of the gaseous chemical (in ppm,
round off to one decimal place), is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} PV&=nRT\\ V&=\frac{nRT}{P}\\ &=\frac{41.6 \times 10^{-6}\times 32.05 \times 10^{-6}}{1} \times 293\\ &=10^{-6}m^3 \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex]41.6\mu[/latex] mole of gas volume of [latex]10^{-6} m^3 [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} 1 ppm&= \frac{\text{1 part of gas}}{10^6 \text{ part of air}} \\ &= \frac{1 m^3\text{ part of gas}}{10^6 m^3\text{ part of air}}\\ 1ppm &=\frac{41.6 \times 10^6 \mu \; moles}{10^6 m^3} \\ 41.6\mu moles/m^3 &=1 ppm \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 85 Surface Overflow Rate (SOR) of a primary settling tank (discrete settling) is 20000 litre/[latex]m^2[/latex]
per day. Kinematic viscosity of water in the tank is [latex]1.01 times 10^{-2} cm^2/s[/latex]. Specific gravity
of the settling particles is 2.64. Acceleration due to gravity is 9.81 [latex]m/s^2[/latex]. The minimum
diameter (in ?m, round off to one decimal place) of the particles that will be removed
with 80% efficiency in the tank, is _________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \eta &=80=\frac{u_s}{v_s}\times 100\\ u_s&=\frac{0.8 \times 20000 \times 10^{-3}}{86400}\\ &=1.85 \times 10^{-4} m/sec\\ u_s&=\frac{(G-1)gd^2}{18v}\\ 1.85 \times 10^{-4}&=\frac{(2.64-1)\times 9.81 \times d^2}{18 \times 1.01 \times 10^{-2} \times 10^{-4}}\\ d&=1.446 \times 10^{-5}m\\ &=14.46\mu m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 86 A water supply scheme transports 10 MLD (Million Litres per Day) water through a 450
mm diameter pipeline for a distance of 2.5 km. A chlorine dose of 3.50 mg/litre is applied
at the starting point of the pipeline to attain a certain level of disinfection at the downward
end. It is decided to increase the flow rate from 10 MLD to 13 MLD in the pipeline. Assume
exponent for concentration, n = 0.86. With this increased flow, in order to attain the same
level of disinfection, the chlorine does (in mg/litre) to be applied at the starting point
should be
solution: Waterson law, [latex]\begin{aligned} tc^h &=\text{Constant} \\ t_1c_1^n&= t_2c_2^n\\ \frac{d_1}{v_1}c_1^n&=\frac{d_2}{v_2}c_2^n \\ \frac{d_1}{Q_1}A_1c_1^n&=\frac{d_2A_2c_2^n}{Q_2} \\ d_1=d_2, \;& A_1=A_2 \\ \frac{(3.5)^{0.86}}{10} &=\frac{(c_2)^{0.86}}{13} \\ c_2 &=\left ( \frac{13}{10} \right )^{1/0.86} \times 3.5 \\ &= 4.747 mg/l \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 87 A river has a flow of 1000 million litres per day (MLD), [latex]BOD_5[/latex] of 5 mg/litre and Dissolved
Oxygen (DO) level of 8 mg/litre before receiving the wastewater discharge at a location.
For the existing environmental conditions, the saturation DO level is 10 mg/litre in the
river. Wastewater discharge of 100 MLD with the [latex]BOD_5[/latex] of 200 mg/litre and DO level of
2 mg/litre falls at that location. Assuming complete mixing of wastewater and river water,
the immediate DO deficit (in mg/litre, round off to two decimal places), is _________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} DO_{mix}&=\frac{DO_{s}Q_s+DO_RQ_R}{Q_s+Q_R}\\ &=\frac{2 \times 100+8 \times 1000}{100+1000}\\ &=7.45 \; \text{mg/l}\\ DO&=DO_{sat}-DO_{mix}\\ &=10-7.45=2.545 \; \text{mg/l} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 88 An amount of 35.67 mg HCI is added to distilled water and the total solution volume
is made to one litre. The atomic weights of H and CI are 1 and 35.5, respectively.
Neglecting the dissociation of water, the pH of the solution, is
solution: [latex]HCI\rightarrow H^+ +CI^-[/latex] 1 mole of HCL gives 1 mole [latex]H^+[/latex] ions 36.5 gm of HCl gives 1 gm of [latex]H^+[/latex] ions [latex]\begin{aligned} 35.67mg&= \frac{1}{36.5}\times 35.67\\ &= 0.977mg \; of \; H^+\\ &=\frac{0.977 \times 10^{-3}}{1} \\ &= 9.77 \times 10^{-4} \; \text{mole of} \; H^+\\ pH &=-\log_{10}[H^+]=-\log_{10}[9.77 \times 10^{-4}] \\ &=-\log_{10}9.77+4\log_{10}10\\ &=4-0.989=3.01 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 89 During chlorination process, aqueous (aq) chlorine reacts rapidly with water to from [latex]CI^-, HOCI[/latex], and [latex]H^+[/latex] as shown below [latex]CI_2(aq)+ H_2O\rightleftharpoons HOCI+CI^-+H^+[/latex] The most active disinfectant in the chlorination process from amongst the following, is
solution: [latex] Cl_2+ H_2O\overset{pH \gt 5}{\rightleftharpoons } HOCl+HCl[/latex] [latex]HOCl \xrightleftharpoons [pH \lt 7]{pH \gt 8} H^+ +OCl^-[/latex] At [latex]pH \lt 5[/latex], chlorine does not react with water and remains as free chlorine. [latex](HOCl^- +OCl^- +cl_2)[/latex] are combinedly called freely available chlorine. Out of these forms of freely available chlorine, [latex]HOCl[/latex] is most destructive. It is 80% more effective than [latex]OCl^-[/latex] ion. Hence, pH of water should be maintained slightly below 7.

question: Question 90 Raw municipal solid waste (MSW) collected from a city contains 70% decomposable material that can be converted to methane. The water content of the decomposable material is 35%. An elemental analysis of the decomposable material yields the following mass percent. C : H : O : N : other = 44 : 6 : 43 : 0.8 : 6.2 The methane production of the decomposable material is governed by the following stoichiometric relation [latex]C_aH_bO_cN_d+nH_2O\rightarrow mCH_4+sCO_2+dNH_3[/latex] Given atomic weights: C=12, H=1, O=16, N=14. The mass of methane produced (in grams, round off to 1 decimal place) per kg of raw MSW will be ______
solution: Let 1 kg of row municipal solid waste (MSW) Decomposable material = 70% of 1 kg = 0.7 kg Water content = 35% Weight of solids in MSW [latex]=\left(\frac{100-35}{100}\right)\times0.7=0.455\;\mathrm{kg}=455\;\mathrm{gms}[/latex] Given: C:H:O:N: other = 44 : 6: 43: 0.8:6.2[latex]\begin{array}{l}\mathrm{Weight}\;\mathrm{of}\;\mathrm C=\frac{(44)}{\left(44+6+43+0.8+6.2\right)}\times455=200.2\;\mathrm{gms}\\\mathrm{Weight}\;\mathrm{of}\;\mathrm H=\frac{\left(6\right)}{\left(44+6+43+0.8+6.2\right)}\times455=27.3\;\mathrm{gms}\\\mathrm{Weight}\;\mathrm{of}\;\mathrm O=\frac{(43)}{\left(44+6+43+0.8+6.2\right)}\times455=195.6\;\mathrm{gms}\\\mathrm{Weight}\;\mathrm{of}\;\mathrm N=\frac{\left(0.8\right)}{\left(44+6+43+0.8+6.2\right)}\times455=3.64\;\mathrm{gms}\\\Rightarrow12\mathrm a=200.2\Rightarrow\mathrm a=16.68\\1\times\mathrm b=27.3\Rightarrow\mathrm b=27.3\\16\times\mathrm c=195.6\Rightarrow\mathrm c=12.225\\14\times\mathrm d=3.64\Rightarrow\mathrm d=0.26\\\mathrm{Now},\;\mathrm{balancing}\;\mathrm{the}\;\mathrm{given}\;\mathrm{stoichiometic}\;\mathrm r\times\mathrm n\\{\mathrm C}_{\mathrm a}{\mathrm H}_{\mathrm b}{\mathrm O}_{\mathrm C}{\mathrm N}_{\mathrm d}+{\mathrm{nH}}_2\mathrm O\rightarrow{\mathrm{mCH}}_4+{\mathrm{SCO}}_2+{\mathrm{dNn}}_3\\12\mathrm a=12\mathrm m+12\mathrm s\Rightarrow12\mathrm m+12\mathrm s=200.2\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\left(12\mathrm a=200.2\right)\\\mathrm b+2\mathrm n=4\mathrm m+3\mathrm d\Rightarrow4\mathrm m-2\mathrm n=26.52\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\left(6=27.3\right)\\16\mathrm c+16\mathrm n=325\Rightarrow\mathrm n=25-12.225\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\left(16\mathrm c=195.6\right)\\\therefore\;\;\;\;\;4\mathrm m-2\left(2\mathrm s-12.225\right)=26.52\\\Rightarrow4\mathrm m-4\mathrm s=2.07\\\Rightarrow12\mathrm m-12\mathrm s=6.21\\\mathrm{Also},\;12\mathrm m+12\mathrm s=200.2\\\Rightarrow\mathrm m=8.6\\\therefore\;\;\mathrm{Mass}\;\mathrm{of}\;\mathrm{methane}\;\mathrm{produced} \\ =16\times\mathrm m=16\times8.6=137.6\;\mathrm{gms}\end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 91 A water treatment plant treats 6000 [latex]m^3[/latex] of water per day. As a part of the treatment process, discrete particles are required to be settled in a clarifier. A column test indicates that an overflow rate of 1.5 m per hour would produce the desired removal of particles through settling in the clarifier having a depth of 3.0 m. The volume of the required clarifier, (in [latex]m^3[/latex], round off to 1 decimal place) would be _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Design discharge, }\\ Q_0&=6000m^3/d\\ \text{Overflow rate}\\ OFR(v_s)&=1.5m/hr\\ SA&=\frac{Q_0}{OFR}\\ \text{Volume,}\; V&=SA \times \text{Depth}(H)\\ &=\frac{Q_0}{OFR} \times H\\ &=\frac{6000 \times 3}{1.5 \times 24}=500m^3 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 92 Chlorine is used as the disinfectant in a municipal water treatment plant. Question 93 Analysis of a water sample revealed that the sample contains the following species. solution: Alkalinity is defined as ability of water to neutralize the acid or hydronium ion [latex]\text{Alkalinity} (A_T) \text{of water} = [HCO_3^-] + [CO_3^{2-}] + [B(OH)_4^-] + [H_3(SiO_4)^-] + [HS^-] + [\text{organic anions}] + [OH^-] - [H^+][/latex] From given options of ions in problem answer is [latex]CO_3^{2-}, H^+, HCO_3^-, OH^-[/latex]

question: Question 94 Which one of the following options contains ONLY primary air pollutants?
solution: Hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxides are considered primary air pollutants.

question: Question 95 A wastewater is to be disinfected with 35 mg/Lof chlorine to obtain 99% kill of micro-organisms. The number of micro-organisms remaining alive ([latex]N_t[/latex]) at time t, is modelled by [latex]N_t=N_oe^{-kt}[/latex], where [latex]N_o[/latex] is number of micro-organisms at t= 0, and k is the rate of kill. The wastewater flow rate is 36 [latex]m^3/hr[/latex], and k= 0.23 [latex]min^{-1}[/latex]. If the depth and width of the chlorination tank are 1.5 m and 1.0 m, respectively, the length of the tank (in m, round off to 2 decimal places) is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} N_t&=N_0e^{-kt}\\ \therefore \; \eta &=[1-e^{-kt}]100\\ 99&=[1-e^{-0.23\times t}]100\\ \therefore \;t&=20.22min\\ Q&=36m^3/hr\\ V&=Q \times t\\ &=\frac{36}{60}\times 20.22=12.0132\\ \text{Length}&=\frac{V}{B \times H}=\frac{12.0132}{1 \times 1.5}\\ &=8.008\cong 8m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 96 A 0.80 m deep bed of sand filter (length 4 m and width 3 m) is made of uniform particles (diameter = 0.40 mm, specific gravity = 2.65, shape factor = 0.85) with bed porosity of 0.4. The bed has to be backwashed at a flow rate of 3.60 [latex]m^3/min[/latex]. During backwashing, if the terminal settling velocity of sand particles is 0.05 m/s, the expanded bed depth (in m, round off to 2 decimal places) is ________
solution: Given, [latex]\begin{aligned} z &=0.8m \\ n &=0.4m \\ Q_B &=3.6m^3/min \\ &= \frac{3.6}{60}m^3/sec=0.06m^3/sec\\ L&=4m \\ B&= 3m\\ V_B&= \frac{Q_B}{A_s}=\frac{Q_B}{LB}\\ &= \frac{0.06}{4 \times 3}=5 \times 10^{-3}m/sec\\ V_s&= 0.05m/sec\\ V_B&=V_s(n_e)^{4.5} \\ (n_e)^{4.5}&= \frac{V_B}{V_s}=\frac{5 \times 10^{-3}}{0.05}\\ n_e&=\left ( \frac{5 \times 10^{-3}}{0.05} \right )^{\frac{1}{4.5}} \\ &= 0.599\simeq 0.6\\ \frac{z_e}{z}&=\frac{1-n}{1-n_e} \\ z_e &=z\left ( \frac{1-n}{1-n_e} \right ) \\ z_e&=0.8 \times \left ( \frac{1-0.4}{1-0.6} \right )=1.2m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 97 A sample of air analysed at 0[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C and 1 atm pressure is reported to contain 0.02 ppm(parts per million) of [latex]NO_2[/latex]. Assume the gram molecular mass of [latex]NO_2[/latex] as 46 and its volume at 0[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C and 1 atm pressure as 22.4 litres per mole. The equivalent [latex]NO_2[/latex] concentration (in microgram per cubic meter, round off to 2 decimalplaces) would be ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} k&=22.4\\ M&=46\\ 0.02\; \text{ppm of}\; NO_2&=0.02 \times \frac{M}{k}\times 10^3 \mu g/m^3\\ &=0.02 \times \frac{46}{22.4}\times 10^{3}\\ &=41.0714\mu g/m^3 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 98 Sedimentation basin in a water treatment plant is designed for a flow rate of 0.2 [latex]m^3/s[/latex]. The basin is rectangular with a length of 32m, width of 8m, and depth of 4m. Assume that the settling velocity of these particles is governed by the Stokes' law. Given: density of the particles = 2.5 [latex]g/cm^3[/latex]; density of water = 1 [latex]g/cm^3[/latex]; dynamic viscosity of water = 0.01 g/(cm.s); gravitational acceleration = 980 [latex]cm/s^2[/latex]. If the incoming water contains particles of diameter 25 [latex]\mu m[/latex](spherical and uniform), the removal efficiency of these particles is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q&=0.2m^3/sec,\; L=32m\\ B&=8m,\; H=4m\\ \rho _p&=2.5gm/cc=2500kg/m^3\\ \rho _w&=1gm/cc=1000kg/m^3\\ \mu &=0.01gm/cm-sec=1 \times 10^{-3}kg/m-sec\\ d&=25\mu m=25 \times 10^{-6}m\\ g&=980cm/sec^2=9.8m/sec^2\\ v_0&=\frac{Q}{A_s}=\frac{Q}{L \times B}\\ &=\frac{0.2}{32 \times 8}=7.8125 \times 10^{-4}m/sec\\ v_s&=\frac{g(\rho _p-\rho _w)d^2}{18\mu }\\ &=\frac{9.8(2500-1000)\times (25 \times 10^{-6})^2}{18 \times (1 \times 10^{-3})}\\ &=5.1041 \times 10^{-4}m/sec\\ \eta &=\frac{v_s}{v_0}\times 100\\ &=\frac{5.1041 \times 10^{-4}}{7.8125 \times 10^{-4}}\times 100\\ &=65.33\%\simeq 65\% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 99 A completely mixed dilute suspension of sand particles having diameters 0.25, 0.35, 0.40, 0.45 and 0.50 mm are filled in a transparent glass column of diameter 10 cm and height 2.50 m. The suspension is allowed to settle without any disturbance. It is observed that all particles of diameter 0.35 mm settle to the bottom of the column in 30 s. For the same period of 30 s, the percentage removal (round off to integer value) of particles of diameters 0.45 and 0.50 mm from the suspension is ____
solution:
Since sand particle of size 0.35 mm settles to the bottom of the column in 30 sec
particles having size greater than 0.35 mm i.e. 0.45 and 0.50 mm will also settle in
suspension at the bottom of column by 100% in 30 sec, infact these bigger sized particle
will settle by 100% in less than 30 sec. So answer is 100%.

question: Question 100 Which one of the following is a secondary pollutant?
solution: Ozone is a dangerous secondary air contaminant.

question: Question 101 A schematic flow diagram of a completely mixed biological reactor with provision for recycling of solids is shown in the figure. The mean cell residence time (in days, up to one decimal place) is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \theta_{C} &=\frac{V X}{\left(Q_{0}-Q_{w}\right) X e+Q_{w} X_{u}} \\ &=\frac{Q_{0} H R T X}{\left(Q_{0}-Q_{w}\right) X_{e}+Q_{w} X_{u}}\left(X_{e}=0\right)\\ &=\frac{15000 \times \frac{2}{24} \times 3000}{50 \times 10000}=7.5 \text{ days} \end{aligned}\\[/latex]

question: Question 102 At a small water treatment plant which has 4 filters, the rates of filtration and backwashing are 200 [latex]m^{3}/d/m^{2}[/latex] and 1000 [latex]m^{3}/d/m^{2}[/latex], respectively. Backwashing is done for 15 min per day. The maturation, which occurs initially as the filter is put back into service after cleaning, takes 30 min. It is proposed to recover the water being wasted during backwashing and maturation. The percentage increase in the filtered water produced (up to two decimal places) would be ______
solution: Let total area of filters be [latex]1 \mathrm{m}^{2} [/latex] Water used for backwashing [latex] =1000 \times \frac{15}{24 \times 60}=10.4166 \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] Water used for maturation [latex] =200 \times \frac{30}{24 \times 60}=4.166 \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] Total water wasted for backwashing and maturation [latex] =10.4166+4.166=14.58 \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] Water to be treated by filtered [latex] =200 \times \frac{23.25}{24}=193.75 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{day}[/latex] % increase in filtered water produced [latex] =\frac{14.58}{193.75} \times 100=7.525 \%[/latex]

question: Question 103 A coal containing 2% sulfur is burned completely to ash in a brick kiln at a rate of 30 kg/min. The sulfur content in the ash was found to be 6% of the initial amount of sulfur present in the coal fed to the brick kiln. The molecular weights of S, H and O are 32, 1 and 16 g/mole, respectively. The annual rate of sulfur dioxide ([latex]SO_{2}[/latex]) emission from the kiln (in tonnes/year, up to two decimal places) is ______
solution: Coal burned in one year [latex]\begin{aligned} &=30\times 24\times 60\times 365 \\ &=1.5768\times 10^{7}\: \text{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Sulfur content=[latex]\frac{2}{100}\times 1.5768\times 10^{7}\times 10^{-6}[/latex] [latex] =315.36\; tonnes/year[/latex] Sulphur content in ash [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\frac{6}{100}\times 315.36 \\ &= 18.92\; tonnes/year \end{aligned}[/latex] Sulphur converted to [latex]SO_{2}=315.36-18.92[/latex] [latex] =296.44\; tonnes/year[/latex] [latex]\; \; \; S\, +\, O_{2}\rightarrow SO_{2}[/latex] 1 mole of S is present in 1 mole of [latex]SO_{2}[/latex] 32 gm of S is present in 64 gm of [latex]SO_{2}[/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] Rate of [latex]SO_{2}[/latex] emission [latex]=\frac{64}{32}\times 296.44=592.88\: tonnes/year[/latex]

question: Question 104 A flocculation tank contains [latex]1800\: m^{3}[/latex] of water, which is mixed using paddles at an average velocity gradient G of 100/s. The water temperature and the corresponding dynamic viscosity are [latex]30^{\circ}C\: \: and \: \: 0.798\times 10^{-3}\: \: Ns/m^{2}[/latex] respectively. The theoretical power required to achieve the stated value of G (in kW, up to two decimal places) is ______
solution: Power required [latex] \begin{aligned} P &=\mu \mathrm{VG}^{2} \\ &=0.798 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{Ns} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \times 1800 \mathrm{m}^{3} \times(1005)^{2} \\ &=14364 \mathrm{Nm} / \mathrm{s} \text { or } \mathrm{Watt} \\ &=14.364 \mathrm{kW} \\ &=14.36 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 108 A waste activated sludge (WAS) is to be blended with green waste (GW). The carbon (C) and nitrogen (N) contents, per kg of WAS and GW, on dry basis are given in the table. The ratio of WAS to GW required (up to two decimal places) to achieve a blended C:N ratio of 20:1 on dry basis is ______
solution: Let 20 kg of C and 1 kg of N is required Let [latex]x[/latex] kg of WAS is taken [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \text{Carbon in x } \mathrm{kg}&=0.054 x \mathrm{kg} \\ \text{ Nitrogen in x } \mathrm{kg}&=0.010 x \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Let y kg of GW is taken [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \text { Carbon in } y \mathrm{kg} &=0.360 \mathrm{y} \mathrm{kg} \\ \text { Nitrogen in } y \mathrm{kg} &=0.006 \mathrm{y} \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Total Carbon, [latex] 0.054 x+0.36 y=20 \mathrm{kg}\quad \quad\ldots(i)[/latex] Total Nitrogen, [latex] \begin{aligned} 0.01 x+0.006 y &=1 \mathrm{kg} &\ldots(ii)\\ x &=73.26 \mathrm{kg} \\ y &=44.566 \mathrm{kg} \\ \frac{x}{y} &=\frac{\mathrm{WAS}}{\mathrm{GW}}\\ \therefore &=1.6438 \simeq 1.64 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 109 The ultimate BOD ([latex]L_{0}[/latex]) of a wastewater sample is estimated as 87% of COD. The COD of this wastewater is 300 mg/L. Considering first order BOD reaction rate constant k (use natural log) = 0.23 per day and temperature coefficient [latex]\theta[/latex] = 1.047, the BOD value (in mg/L,
up to one decimal place) after three days of incubation at [latex]27^{\circ}[/latex]C for this wastewater will be______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Ultimate BOD} &=0.87\; \text{COD} \\ &=0.87\times 300=261\: mg/l \\ BOD_{3}&=L_{0}\left ( 1-e^{-k_{27}\times 3} \right ) \\ k_{27}&=k_{20}\left ( 1.047 \right )^{T-20} \end{aligned}[/latex] For municipal sewage, at standard temperature, value of k(base e)=0.23 per day. Thus, value 0.23 per day given is w.r.t. the standard temperature of [latex]20^{\circ}C[/latex]. [latex]\begin{aligned} &=0.23\left ( 1.047 \right )^{27-20} \\ &=0.317\; day^{-1} \\ BOD_{3} &=261\left ( 1-e^{-0.317\times 3} \right ) \\ &= 160.226\; mg/l \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 110 A water sample analysis data is given below. The carbonate hardness (expressed as mg/L of [latex]CaCo_{3}[/latex] , up to one decimal place) for the water sample is ______
solution: Carbonate hardness = min. (Total hardness, alkalinity) Total hardness [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\left(\frac{60}{20} \times 50+\frac{30}{12.155} \times 50\right) \mathrm{mg} / l as \mathrm{CaCO}_{3} \\ &=150+123.406 \\ &=273.406 \mathrm{mg} / l as \mathrm{CaCO}_{3} \\ &\text{Alkalinity }=\left(\frac{400}{61} \times 50\right) \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{l} as \mathrm{CaCO}_{3} \\ &=327.868 \mathrm{mg} / l as \mathrm{CaCO}_{3} \\ & \therefore \quad \mathrm{CH}=273.4 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{l} as \mathrm{CaCO}_{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]
