Question 112 A city generates [latex]40 \times 10^{6}[/latex] kg of municipal solid waste (MSW) per year, out of which only 10% is recovered/recycled and the rest goes to landfill. The landfill has a single lift of 3 m height and is compacted to a density of [latex]550 kg/m^{3}[/latex]. If 80% of the landfill is assumed to be MSW, the landfill area (in [latex]m^{2}[/latex], up to one decimal place) required would be ______
solution: Total weight generated by city [latex]=40\times 10^{6}\: kg/year[/latex] Weight of MSW going into landfill [latex]=0.9\times 40\times 10^{6}\: kg/year[/latex] [latex]=36\times 10^{6}\: kg/year[/latex] Compacted density [latex]=550\: kg/m^{3}[/latex] Compacted volume of MSW [latex]=\frac{36\times 10^{6}\: kg/year}{550\: kg/m^{3}}[/latex] [latex]=65454.5454\: m^{3}/year[/latex] Total landfill volume = Vol. of MSD + Vol. of cover Given, Volume of MSW [latex]=0.8\times[/latex] Total landfill volume [latex]\therefore[/latex] Vol. of cover [latex] =0.2\times [/latex] Total landfill volume [latex] \therefore [/latex]Total landfill volume [latex] =\frac{65454.5454}{0.8}m^{3}/year =81818.18175m^{3}/year[/latex] Height of landfill [latex]=3\: m[/latex] [latex]\therefore [/latex] Area of lanfill[latex]=\frac{81818.18175}{3} =27272.7\: m^{2}/year[/latex]

question: Question 113 There are 20,000 vehicles operating in a city with an average annual travel of 12,000 km per vehicle. The [latex]NO_x[/latex] emission rate is 2.0 g/km per vehicle. The total annual release of [latex]NO_x[/latex] will be
solution: Total no. of kms. Travelled by all the vehicles [latex]=20000\times 12000\: km=24\times 10^{7}\: km[/latex] Total [latex]NO_{x}[/latex] emission [latex]=2\: g/km\times 24\times 10^{7}\: km[/latex] [latex]=48\times 10^{7}\: g[/latex] [latex]=48\times 10^{4}\: kg[/latex]

question: Question 115 A municipal corporation is required to treat 1000 [latex]m^{3}/day[/latex] of water. It is found that an overflow rate of 20 m/day will produce a satisfactory removal of the discrete suspended particles at a depth of 3 m. The diameter (in meters, rounded to the nearest integer) of a circular settling tank designed for the removal of these particles would be______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q_{0} &=1000 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{d} \\ \mathrm{OFR} &=20 \mathrm{MLD} \\ \mathrm{SA} &=\frac{Q_{0}}{\mathrm{OFR}}=\frac{1000}{20}=50 \mathrm{m}^{2}\\ S A&=\frac{\pi D^{2}}{4}=50 \\ \Rightarrow \quad D&=7.98 \mathrm{m} \simeq 8 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 116 For a given water sample, the ratio between [latex]BOD_{5-day,20^{\circ}C}[/latex] and the ultimate BOD is 0.68. The value of the reaction rate constant k (on base e) (in [latex]day^{-1}[/latex] up to two decimal places) is_____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} BOD/20^{\circ}C &=C_{0}\left ( 1-e^{-k\: 20^{\circ}C\times 5} \right ) \\ \frac{BOD/20^{\circ}C}{C_{0}} &=0.68=\left ( 1-e^{-k\: 20^{\circ}C\times 5} \right ) \\ K,20^{\circ}C &=0.227\; day^{-1}\simeq 0.23\; day^{-1} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 117 The composition of a municipal solid waste sample is given below: The difference between the energy content of the waste sample calculated on dry basis and asdiscarded basis (in kJ/kg) would be
solution: Energy on dry basis: It will be the total energy when whole mass is dry In current situation only 60% mass is dry energy corresponding to 60% dry mass=5805 kJ/kg Energy corresponding to 100% dry mass=[latex]\frac{5805}{60}\times 100=9675\: kJ/kg[/latex] So, energy as on dry basis=9675 kJ/kg Energy based on as discharged basis=5805 kJ/kg So, difference=9675-5805=3870 kJ/kg

Question 121 The wastewater having an organic concentration of 54 mg/l is flowing at a steady rate of 0.8 [latex] m^{3}/day [/latex] through a detention tank of dimensions [latex]2m\times 4m\times 2m[/latex]. If the contents of the tankare well mixed and the decay constant is 0.1 per day, the outlet concentration (in mg/l, up to one decimal place) is ______
solution: [latex]Q=0.8 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{d}[/latex] Detention time, [latex] \begin{aligned} D_{t}&=\frac{V}{Q}=\frac{4 \times 2 \times 2 \mathrm{m}^{3}}{0.8 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{day}}=20 \mathrm{days} \\ L_{t}&=\frac{L_{0}}{1+k_{\mathrm{e}} t}=\frac{54}{1+0.1 \times 20}=18 \mathrm{mg} / l \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 122 Two wastewater streams A and B, having an identical ultimate BOD are getting mixed to form the stream C. The temperature of the stream A is 20[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C and the temperature of the stream C is 10[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. It is given that The 5-day BOD of the stream A measured at 20[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C=50 mg/l BOD rate constant (base 10) at 20[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C=0.115 per day Temperature coefficient = 1.135 The 5-day BOD (in mg/l, up to one decimal place)of stream C, calculated at 10[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C, is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{At A,}\; \; \; \left ( BOD_{5} \right )_{20^{\circ}C}&=L\left ( 1-10^{-k_{D}20^{\circ}C\times 5} \right ) \\ 50 &=L\left ( 1-10^{-0.115\times 5} \right ) \\ L&= 68.129\; mg/l\\ \text{Here,} \; \; k_{D_{10}}&=k_{D_{20}}\times \left [ 1.135 \right ]^{10-20} \\ &=0.115\times \left ( 1.135 \right )^{-10} \\ &=0.0324 \\ \text{For C,}\; \;\left ( BOD_{5} \right )_{10^{\circ}C} &=L\left [ 1-10^{-k_{D_{10\times 4}}} \right ] \\ &=68.13\left [ 1-10^{-0.0324\times 5} \right ] \\ &=21.21\; mg/l \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 123 The spherical grit particles, having a radius of 0.01mm and specific gravity of 3.0, need to beseparated in a settling chamber. It is given that [latex]g=9.81 \; m/s^{2} [/latex] the density of the liquid in the settling chamber [latex] =1000 \; kg/m^{3} [/latex] the kinematic viscosity of the liquid in the settling chamber = [latex]10^{-6} \; m^{2}/s[/latex] Assuming laminar conditions, the settling velocity (in mm/s, up to one decimal place) is_____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} v_{s} &=\frac{(G-1) g d^{2}}{18 v}=\frac{(3-1) 9.81\left(0.02 \times 10^{-3}\right)^{2}}{18 \times 10^{-6}} \times 10^{3} \\ &=0.436 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 124 The equivalent sound power level (in dB) of the four sources with the noise levels of 60 dB, 69 dB, 70 dB and 79 dB is_______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} L_{eq} &=10\log_{10}\left [ \sum 10^{\frac{L_{i}}{10}} \right ] \\ &=10\log_{10}\left ( 10^{\frac{60}{10}}+10^{\frac{69}{10}}+10^{\frac{70}{10}}+10^{\frac{79}{10}} \right ) \\ &=79.9\: \text{dB} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 126 The wastewater form a city, containing a high concentration of biodegradable organics, is beingsteadily discharged into a flowing river at a location S. question: Question 127 For a wastewater sample, the three-day biochemical oxygen demand at incubation temperature of [latex]20\: ^{\circ}C \; (BOD_{3days,20{\circ}C})[/latex], is estimated as 200 mg/L. Taking the value of the first order BOD reaction rate constant as [latex]0.22\: day^{-1}[/latex], the five-day BOD (expressed in mg/L) of the wastewater at incubation temperature of  [latex]20\: ^{\circ}C[/latex] [latex](BOD_{5days,20{\circ}C})[/latex] would be ___________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} BOD_{5} &=L_{0}\left ( 1-e^{-0.22\times 5} \right ) \\ BOD_{3}&=L_{0}\left ( 1-e^{-0.22\times 3} \right ) \end{aligned}[/latex] From equation (i) and (ii), we get, [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{BOD_{5}}{BOD_{3}} &=\frac{\left ( 1-e^{-0.22\times 5} \right )}{\left ( 1-e^{-0.22\times 3} \right )} \\ BOD_{5} &=200\times \frac{0.667}{0.483} \\ &=200\times 1.38 \\ &=276.19\: mg/l \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 128 A noise meter located at a distance of 30 m from a point source recorded 74 dB . The reading at a distance of 60 m from the point source would be _________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} L_{2} &=L_{1}-\left | 20\log \left ( \frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}} \right ) \right | \\ &=74-\left | 20\log 0.5 \right | \\ &=74-6.02 \\ &=74-20\log 0.5 \\ &= 67.98\: dB \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 129 A sample of water has been analyzed for common ions and results are presented in the form of a bar diagram as shown. The non-carbonate hardness (expressed in mg/L as [latex]CaCO_{3}[/latex] ) of the sample is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{Ca}^{2+} &=2.65 \mathrm{meq} / \mathrm{l} \\ \mathrm{Mg}^{2+} &=1.45 \mathrm{meq} / 1 \\ \mathrm{Na}^{+} &=2.25 \mathrm{meq} / l \\ \mathrm{K}^{+} &=0.5 \mathrm{meq} / \mathrm{l} \\ \mathrm{HCO}_{3} &=3.3 \mathrm{meq} / \mathrm{l} \\ \mathrm{SO}_{4}^{2-} &=0.6 \mathrm{meq} / \mathrm{l} \\ \mathrm{Cl}^{-} &=2.85 \mathrm{meq} / \mathrm{l} \end{aligned}[/latex] Hardness is due to multivalent metallic cations, [latex] \mathrm{Ca}^{2+} and \mathrm{Mg}^{2+} [/latex] Total hardness [latex]\left(\mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{l}\text{ as }\mathrm{CaCO}_{3}\right)[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} &=(\text{Total }meq/l) \times (\text{eq. weight of }\mathrm{CaCO}_{3}\text{ in }\mathrm{mg} )\\ &=(2.65+1.45) \times 50 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{l} \text { as } \mathrm{CaCO}_{3} \\ &=205 \mathrm{mg} / l \text { as } \mathrm{CaCO}_{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Alkalinity is due to the presence of [latex]\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}[/latex] in this case, Alkalinity [latex]\left(\mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{l}\right. as \left.\mathrm{CaCO}_{3}\right) [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} =3.3 \times 50 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{l} \text { as } \mathrm{CaCO}_{3} \\ =165 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{l} \text { as } \mathrm{CaCO}_{3} \end{array}[/latex] Now, Carbonate Hardness = Min { Total Hardness, Alkalinity } [latex] =165 \mathrm{mg} / l[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Non-carbonate hardness = Total Hardness - Carbonate Hardness [latex] =205-165=40 \mathrm{mg} / l as \mathrm{CaCO}_{3}[/latex]

question: Question 130 A tracer takes 100 days to travel from Well-1 to Well-2 which are 100 m apart. The elevation of water surface in Well-2 is 3m below that in Well-1. Assuming porosity equal to 15%, the coefficient of permeability (expressed in m/day) is
solution: Seepage velocity, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{s}&=\frac{v}{n}=\frac{\text { distance }}{\text { time }}\\ \text{as per Darcy},\\ v &=k i \\ \frac{k i}{n} &=\frac{100 \mathrm{m}}{100 \mathrm{days}} \\ i &=\frac{\text { head difference }}{\text { length }}=\frac{3}{100} \\ \frac{k \times 3}{0.15 \times 100} &=\frac{100}{100} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{day} \\ k &=5 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{day} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 131 The sound pressure (expressed in [latex]\mu Pa[/latex] ) of the faintest sound that a normal healthy individual can hear is
solution: The sound pressure of the faintest sound that can be heard by a normal healthy individual is about 20 [latex]\mu Pa[/latex]. Hence, this pressure is used as reference pressure in determination of sound pressure level. A 20 [latex]\mu Pa[/latex] pressure is 0dB on the sound pressure level scale.

question: Question 132 The hardness of a ground water sample was found to be 420 mg/L as [latex]CaCO_{3}[/latex].  A softener containing ion exchange resins was installed to reduce the total hardness to 75 mg/L as [latex]CaCO_{3}[/latex]  before supplying to 4 households. Each household gets treated water at a rate of 540 L/day. If the efficiency of the softener is 100%, the bypass flow rate (expressed in L/day) is _____________.
solution: Total water to be treated [latex] =540 \times 4=2160 \text {L/ day }[/latex] Resultant hardness required [latex] =75 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{L}[/latex] Let bypass rate be x L/day having hardness of 420 mg / L Resultant hardness required [latex] \begin{aligned} &=75 \mathrm{mg} / L \\ \mathrm{CH}_{\operatorname{mix}} &=\frac{\mathrm{CH}_{1} \mathrm{Q}_{1}+\mathrm{CH}_{2} \mathrm{Q}_{2}}{\mathrm{Q}} \\ 75 &=\frac{x \times 420+(2160-x) 0}{2160} \\ x &=\frac{2160 \times 75}{420}=385.7 \; L / \mathrm{day} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 133 A water supply board is responsible for treating 1500 [latex]m^{3}/day[/latex] of water. A settling column analysis indicates that an overflow rate of 20 m/day will produce satisfactory removal for a depth of 3.1 m. It is decided to have two circular settling tanks in parallel. The required diameter (expressed in m) of the settling tanks is ___________.
solution: Discharge to be treated by one tank, [latex] \begin{aligned} Q=\frac{1500}{2}&=750 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{day} \\ \text{Surface area, } A&=\frac{Q}{O F R}=\frac{750}{20}=37.5 \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 37.5&=\pi \times \frac{d^{2}}{4} \\ \Rightarrow \quad d&=6.91 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 134 The atmospheric layer closest to the earth surface is

Question 135 Water table of an aquifer drops by 100 cm over an area of 1000[latex] km^{2}[/latex]. The porosity and specific retention of the aquifer material are 25% and 5%, respectively. The amount of water (expressed in [latex]km^{3}[/latex] ) drained out from the area is ______ .
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} S_{\mathrm{r}}+S_{\mathrm{y}} &=n \\ \frac{5}{100}+\frac{V_{\mathrm{w}}}{10^{3} \times 10^{6} \times 1} &=\frac{25}{100} \\ V_{\mathrm{w}} &=0.2 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{m}^{3}=0.2 \mathrm{km}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 136 The 2-day and 4-day BOD values of a sewage sample are 100 mg/L and 155 mg/L, respectively. The value of BOD rate constant (expressed in per day) is ___________

Question 137 An electrostatic precipitator (ESP) with 5600 [latex]m^{2}[/latex] of collector plate area is 96 percent efficient in treating 185[latex]m^{3}/s[/latex] of flue gas from a 200 MW thermal power plant. It was found that in order to achieve 97 percent efficiency, the collector plate area should be 6100 [latex]m^{2}[/latex]. In order to increase the efficiency to 99 percent, the ESP collector plate area (expressed in [latex]m^{2}[/latex] ) would be ______
solution: As per Deutsch-Anderson equation, to determine the collection efficiency of the precipitator under ideal conditions, [latex]\begin{aligned} \eta &=1-e^{-w\left ( A/Q \right )} \\ \eta &=\text{Collection efficiency of the precipitator} \\ w &=\text{Migration velocity,}\: cm/s \\ A &=\text{The effective collecting plate area of the precipitator,}\: m^{2} \\ Q &=\text{Gas flow through the precipitator,}\: m^{3}/s \\ 0.96&=1-e^{-\left ( \frac{w}{Q} \right )\times 5600}\; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; ...\left ( i \right ) \\ 0.97 &=1-e^{-\left ( \frac{w}{Q} \right )\times 6100}\; \; \; \; \; \; \; ...\left ( ii \right ) \end{aligned}[/latex] From both equations, [latex]\; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \frac{w}{Q}=5.748\times 10^{-4}[/latex] Now for 99% efficiency plate area required, [latex]0.99=1-e^{-5.748\times 10^{-4}\times A}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; \; \; \; \; A=8011.78\: m^{2}[/latex]

question: Question 138 Effluent from an industry 'A' has a pH of 4.2. The effluent from another industry 'B' has double the hydroxyl ([latex]OH^{-}[/latex]) ion concentration than the effluent from industry 'A'. pH of effluent from the industry 'B' will be ____________.
solution: pH of Effluent from on industry [latex]A=4.2 [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \because \quad \mathrm{pH}+\mathrm{pOH} &=14 \\ \Rightarrow \quad\mathrm{pOH} &=14-4.2=9.8 \\ \Rightarrow \quad -\log \left[\mathrm{OH}^{-}\right] &=9.8 \\ \left[\mathrm{OH}^{-}\right] &=1.5898 \times 10^{-10}(\mathrm{mol} / \mathrm{lit.}) \end{aligned} [/latex] So [latex]\left[\mathrm{OH}^{-}\right][/latex] of effluent from on industry, [latex] \begin{aligned} B&=2 \times[\mathrm{OH}]_{A}\\ \left[\mathrm{OH}^{-}\right]_{B} &=3.6196 \times 10^{-10} \\ \therefore \quad [\mathrm{pOH}]_{B} &=9.5 \\ \therefore \quad [\mathrm{pH}]_{B} &=14-9.5 \\ [\mathrm{pH}]_{B} &=4.5 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 139 Match the items in Group-I with those in Group-II and choose the right combination.

Question 140 It was decided to construct a fabric filter, using bags of 0.45 m diameter and 7.5 m long, for removing industrial stack gas containing particulates. The expected rate of airflow into the filter is 10 [latex]m^{3}/s[/latex]. If the filtering velocity is 2.0 m/min, the minimum number of bags (rounded to nearest higher integer) required for continuous cleaning operation is
solution: Surface area of one bag [latex]=\pi \times d\times l[/latex] [latex]=\pi \times 0.45\times 7.5[/latex] [latex]=10.6028\; m^{2}[/latex] The required area of fabric filter [latex]=\frac{10}{\left ( \frac{2}{60} \right )}=300\; m^{2}[/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] Number of bag required [latex]=\frac{300}{10.6028}=28.294[/latex] So No. of bag required will be 29

question: Question 141 Crown corrosion in a reinforced concrete sewer is caused by:
solution: Bacteria in the slime under flowing sewage convert sulphate in the sewage in sulphides. Sulphidesnin the liquid make their way to the surface of the sewage and reduce into the sewer atmosphere or Hydrogen Sulphide [latex](H_{2}S)[/latex] gas. Bacterial action converts atmospheric [latex]H_{2}S[/latex] gas to Sulphuric Acid which causes corrosion in the crown of the pipe and this corrosion is called crown corrosion.

question: Question 142 Pre-cursors to photochemical oxidants are
solution: Photochemical smog is formed in the atmosphere when pre-cursor pollutants including Nitrogen Oxide ([latex]NO_{X}[/latex]) and Volatile Organic Compounds ([latex]VOC_s[/latex]) undergo reaction in sunlight to form smog, of which ozone is the principle component.

question: Question 143 In a wastewater treatment plant, primary sedimentation tank (PST) designed at an overflow rate of 32.5 [latex]m^{3}/day/m^{2}[/latex] is 32.5 m long, 8.0 m wide and liquid depth of 2.25 m. If the length of the weir is 75 m, the weir loading rate (in [latex]m^{3}/day/m[/latex]) is ___________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{0} &=\frac{Q}{B L} \\ Q &=\left(32.5 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{d} / \mathrm{m}^{2}\right) \times 32.5 \times 8 \\ &=8450 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{d}\\ \text{Weir length }&=75 \mathrm{m} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Weir loading rate, [latex] q=\frac{8450}{75}=112.67 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{d} / \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question: Question 144 Ultimate BOD of a river water sample is 20 mg/L. BOD rate constant (natural log) is 0.15 [latex]day^{-1}[/latex]. The respective values of BOD (in %) exerted and remaining after 7 days are:
solution: BOD remaining FTER 7 DAYS [latex]\begin{aligned} &=BOD_{u}e^{-kt} \\ &=20\times e^{-0.15\times 7} \\ &=20\times 0.35=7 \\ \%: remaining &=\frac{7\times 100}{20}=35\% \end{aligned}[/latex] BOD exerted in 7 days [latex] =\left ( 100-35 \right )\%=65\%[/latex]

question: Question 145 A water treatment plant of capacity,[latex]1\: m^{3}/s[/latex] has filter boxes of dimensions 6m x 10m. Loading rate to the filters is [latex]120 m^{3}/day/m^{2}[/latex]. When two of the filters are out of service for back washing, the loading rate (in [latex]m^{3}/day/m^{2}[/latex])is_______.
solution: Total water filtered in a day [latex] =60 \times 60 \times 24=86400 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{day} [/latex] Total surface area of filter required [latex] =\frac{86400 m^{3} / d a y}{120 m^{3} / d a y / m^{2}}=720 m^{2} [/latex] Area of one filter [latex] =6 \times 10=60 \mathrm{m}^{2} [/latex] Total no. of filter [latex]=\frac{720}{60}=12\text{ filtres }[/latex] As two filters are out of service, number of filters working =12-2=10 Total surface area of filter [latex] =60 \times 10=600 \mathrm{m}^{2} [/latex] The new loading rate [latex] =\frac{86400 m^{3} / d a y}{600 m^{2}}=144 m^{3} / d a y / m^{2}[/latex]

question: Question 146 A landfill is to be designed to serve a population of 200000 for a period of 25 years. The solid waste (SW) generation is 2 kg/person/day. The density of the un-compacted SW is 100 kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex] and a compaction ratio of 4 is suggested. The ratio of compacted fill (i.e. SW + cover) to compacted SW is 1.5. The landfill volume (in million [latex]m^{3}[/latex] ) required is _______.
solution: Solid waste generated per day [latex]=2\times 200000=400000\: kg[/latex] Total solid waste generated in 25 years [latex]=400000\times 365\times 25=3.65\times 10^{9}\: kg[/latex] Compaction ratio, [latex] 4=\frac{Volume\; before\; compaction}{Volume\; after\; compaction}[/latex] Volume of waste before compaction, [latex]V=\frac{3.65\times 10^{9}}{100}=3.65\times 10^{7}\: m^{3}[/latex] Volume of waste after compaction, [latex]V'=\frac{3.65\times 10^{7}}{4}=9.125\times 10^{6}\: m^{3}[/latex] [latex]\frac{SW+cover}{SW}=\frac{SW}{SW}+\frac{cover}{SW}=1.5[/latex] [latex]\frac{Cover}{SW}=0.5[/latex] [latex]Cover=0.5\times 9.125\times 10^{6}[/latex] [latex]\; \; \; =4.5625\times 10^{6}\: m^{3}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Total volume} &=SW+Cover \\ &=\left ( 9.125+4.5625 \right )\times 10^{6}\: m^{3} \\ &=13.6875\: million\: m^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 147 [latex]SO_2[/latex] and CO adversely affect

options.A: oxygen carrying capacity of blood and functioning of lungs respectively
options.B: functioning of the respiratory system and brain respectively
options.C: functioning of the respiratory system and oxygen carrying capacity of blood respectively
options.D: functioning of air passages and chest respectively.

question: Question 148 A groundwater sample was found to contain 500 mg/L total dissolved solids (TDS). TDS (in %) present in the sample is ________.
solution: [latex]1 \mathrm{kg}=1 \text { litre }[/latex] TDS (in %) in the sample [latex] =\frac{500 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{g}}{1000 \mathrm{g}} \times 100=0.05 \%[/latex]

question: Question 149 The relationship between porosity ([latex]\eta[/latex]), specific yield ([latex]S_{y}[/latex]) and specific retention ([latex]S_{r}[/latex]) of an unconfined aquifer is:

Question 150 Consider a primary sedimentation tank (PST) in a water treatment plant with Surface Overflow Rate (SOR) of 40 [latex]m^{3}/m^2/d[/latex]. The diameter of the spherical particle which will have 90 percent theoretical removal efficiency in this tank is_________ [latex]\mu m[/latex]. Assume that settling velocity of the particle in water described by Stokes' Law. Given: Density of water = 1000 [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex]; Density of particle = 2650 [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex]; g = 9.81[latex]m/s^{2}[/latex]; Kinematic viscosity of water [latex](v) = 1.10 \times 10^{-6} m^{2}/s[/latex]
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { \% removal } &=\frac{V_{s}^{\prime}}{V_{s}} \times 100 \\ V_{s}^{\prime} &=0.9 \times V_{s} \\ &=0.9 \times \text { Overfiow rate } \\ V_{s}^{\prime} &=\frac{0.9 \times 40}{86400} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ \frac{(G-1) g d^{2}}{18 \mathrm{v}} &=\frac{0.9 \times 40}{86400} \\ d &=\sqrt{\frac{0.9 \times 40 \times 18 \mathrm{p}_{\mathrm{w}} \mathrm{V}}{86400 \times\left(G_{s}-1\right) \times \rho_{\mathrm{w}} \times g}} \\ &=\sqrt{\frac{0.9 \times 40 \times 18 \times 1.1 \times 10^{-6}}{86400 \times 1.64 \times 9.81}} \\ &=2.2576 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{m}=22.576 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 151 The concentration of Sulfur Dioxide ([latex]SO_{2}[/latex]) in ambient atmosphere was measured as 30 [latex]\mu g/m^{3}[/latex]. Under the same conditions, the above [latex]SO_{2}[/latex] concentration expressed in ppm is ___________. Given: (P/(RT) = 41.6 [latex]mol/m^{3}[/latex]; where, P=Pressure; T=Temperature; R=universal gas constant; Molecular weight of [latex]SO_{2}[/latex]= 64.
solution: 1 [latex]m^{3}[/latex] of air has 30[latex]\mu g\; \; SO_{2}[/latex] [latex]10^{6}[/latex][latex]m^{3}[/latex] of air has 30g [latex]SO_{2}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} 30g\; SO_{2} &=\frac{30}{64}\text{mole}\; SO_{2} \\ \text{From}\; PV &=nRT \\ V &=\frac{nRT}{P}=\frac{n}{P/RT} \\ &=\frac{\left ( 30/64 \right )}{41.6\; mol/m^{3}} \\ \text{Volume of}SO_{2} &=\frac{30}{64\times 41.6} \\ &=0.01127\; m^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow[/latex] Concentration of [latex]SO_{2}[/latex] in PPM=0.0113 ppm

question: Question 152 Solid waste generated from an industry contains only two components, X and Y as shown in the table below Assuming ([latex]c_1+c_2[/latex])=100, the composite density of the solid waste [latex](\rho )[/latex] is given by :
solution: Let density of sludge is [latex]\rho [/latex], [latex]\therefore \; \; \frac{c_{1}+c_{2}}{\rho }=\frac{c_{1}}{\rho _{1}}+\frac{c_{2}}{\rho _{2}}[/latex] Assuming [latex]c_{1}+c_{2}=100[/latex] [latex]\therefore \; \; \rho =\frac{100}{\frac{c_{1}}{\rho _{1}}+\frac{c_{2}}{\rho _{2}}}[/latex]

question: Question 153 Total Kjeldahal Nitrogen (TKN) concentration (mg/L as N) in domestic sewage is the sum of the concentration of :
solution: Kjehldahl Nitrogen=Organic nitrogen+Free ammonia.

options.A: organic and inorganic nitrogen  in sewage
options.B: organic nitrogen and nitrate in sewage
options.C: organic nitrogen and ammonia in sewage

question: Question 154 A waste water stream (flow=2 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/s, ultimate BOD=90 mg/l) is joining a small river (flow=12 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/s, ultimate BOD=5 mg/l). Both water streams get mixed up instantaneously. Cross sectional area of the river is 50 [latex]m^{2}[/latex]. Assuming the de-oxygenation rate constant, k'=0.25/day the BOD (in mg/l) of the river water, 10 km downstream of the mixing point is
solution: Flow of waste water stream, [latex] Q_{w}=2 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{sec}[/latex] Ultimate BOD, [latex] Y_{w}=90 \mathrm{mg} / l=90 \mathrm{gm} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] Flow of river, [latex] Q_{R}=12 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{sec}[/latex] Ultimate BOD of river, [latex] Y_{R}=0.5 \mathrm{mg} / l=5 \mathrm{gm} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] BOD of mixture, [latex] \begin{aligned} Y_{0} &=\frac{(2 \times 90)+(12 \times 5)}{2+12} \\ &=\frac{180+60}{14}=\frac{240}{14} \\ &=17.143 \mathrm{gm} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ k_{D} &=0.434 \mathrm{K} \\ &=0.434 \times 0.25=0.1085 \\ Y_{t} &=Y_{0}\left[1-(10)^{-k_{0} t}\right] &\ldots(i)\\ \text { Area of river } &=50 \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ \text { Flow of river } &=12 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{sec} \\ \text { Stream velocity } &=\frac{14}{50}=0.28 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{sec} \\ \text { Time taken, } & t=\frac{10 \mathrm{km}}{0.28 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}}=0.4133 \text { days } \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\therefore [/latex] From eq. (i), [latex] \begin{aligned} \mathrm{BOD}_{\text {left }} &=Y_{0}-Y_{t} \\ &=Y_{0} \times 10^{-k t} \\ &=17.143 \times 10^{-0.1085 \times 0.4133} \\ &=15.46 \mathrm{mg} / l \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 155 An effluent at a flow rate of 2670 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/d from a sewage treatment plant is to be disinfected. The laboratory data of disinfection studies with a chlorine dosage of 15 mg/l yield the model [latex]N_{t}=N_{o}e^{-0.145t}[/latex]  where [latex]N_t[/latex]= number of micro-organisms surviving at time t (in min.) and [latex]N_o[/latex]= number of micro-organism present initially (at t=0). The volume of disinfection unit (in [latex]m^{3}[/latex]) required to achieve a 98% kill of micro-organisms is______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q&=2670 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{d} \\ N_{t}&=\mathrm{No} . \mathrm{e}^{-0.145 \mathrm{t}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Let x be the no. of microorganisms (M.O.) present initially. 98% kill of M.O. imlies that at time 't' 2% of M.O. are still surviving [latex] \therefore [/latex] M.O. surviving at time 't' [latex]=\frac{2}{100} x [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \frac{2}{100} x &=x \cdot \mathrm{e}^{-0.145 \mathrm{t}} \\ \therefore \qquad t &=26.979 \mathrm{min} \\ t &=0.018736 \text { days } \\ \therefore \qquad \text { Volume } &=Q . t \\ &=2670 \times 0.018736 \\ &=50.0244 \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 156 A surface water treatment plant operates round the clock with a flow rate of 35 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/min. The water temperature is [latex]15^{\circ}C[/latex] and jar testing indicated an alum dosage of 25 mg/l with flocculation at a Gt value of [latex]4\times 10^{4}[/latex] producing optimal result. The alum quantity required for 30 days (in kg) of operation of the plant is
solution: Given data [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Flow rate, } & Q=35 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{min} \\ & G t=4 \times 10^{4} \\ \text { Alum dosage } &=25 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{lit} . \end{aligned}[/latex] Alum quantity (kg) required for 30 days [latex] =35 \times 10^{3} \times 60 \times 24 \times 30 \times 25 \times 10^{-6} [/latex] [latex] =37,800 \mathrm{kg}[/latex]

question: Question 157 A suspension of sand like particles in water with particles of diameter 0.10 mm and below is flowing into a settling tank at 0.10 [latex]m^3[/latex]/s. Assume g=9.81 m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex], specific gravity of particles=2.65, and kinematic vescosity of water=[latex]1.0105 \times 10^{-2} cm^{2}[/latex]/s. The minimum surface area (in [latex]m^{2}[/latex]) required for this settling tank to remove particles of size 0.06 mm and above with 100% efficiency is_________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{s} &=\frac{\left(G_{s}-1\right) g d^{2}}{18 v} \\ &=\frac{(2.65-1) \times 9.81 \times\left(6 \times 10^{-2}\right)^{2}}{18 \times 1.0105 \times 10^{-2}} \\ &=\frac{1.65 \times 9.81 \times 36 \times 10^{-4}}{18 \times 1.0105 \times 10^{-2} \times 10^{2}} \\ &=3.204 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ V_{s} &=\frac{Q}{B L} \\ \Rightarrow\quad B L &=\frac{0.1}{3.204 \times 10^{-3}}=31.214 \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 160 For a sample of water with the ionic composition shown in the figure below, the carbonate and non-carbonate hardness concentrations (in mg/l as [latex]CaCO_{3}[/latex]), respectivelyare:
solution: 1. Carbonate hardness [latex]=3.5 \times 10^{-3}[/latex] g-eq [if NCH is present sodium alkalinity will be absent i.e. [latex] \mathrm{NaHCO}_{3}[/latex] absent] [latex] =3.5 \times 10^{-3} \times \frac{50 g}{1} as \mathrm{CaCO}_{3} [/latex] [latex] =175 \mathrm{mg} / l\text{ as }\mathrm{CaCO}_{3} [/latex] 2. Non carbonate hardness = total hardness carbonate hardness 3. Total hardness [latex]=5 \times 50 \mathrm{mg} / l\text{ as }\mathrm{CaCO}_{3}[/latex] [total hardness is due to [latex]\mathrm{Ca}^{2}+ and \mathrm{Mg}^{2+}[/latex] ] [latex] =250 \mathrm{mg} / l \text{ as } \mathrm{CaCO}_{3} [/latex] [latex] \mathrm{NCH}=250-175=75 \mathrm{mg} / l \text{ as } \mathrm{CaCO}_{3}[/latex]

question: Question 161 The potable water is prepared from turbid surface water by adopting the following treatment sequence.

question: Question 162 16 MLD of water is flowing through a 2.5 km long pipe of diameter 45 cm. The chlorine at the rate of 32 kg/d is applied at the entry of this pipe so that disinfected water is obtained at the exit. There is a proposal to increase the flow through this pipe to 22 MLD from 16 MLD. Assume the dilution coefficient, n = 1. The minimum amount of chlorine (in kg per day) to be applied to achieve the same degree of disinfection for the enhanced flow is
solution: In the disinfection process we have the relationship, [latex]\begin{aligned} tC^{n} &=K \\ \text{where}\; \;t &=\text{time required to kill all organism} \\ \text{c} &=\text{concentration of disinfectant} \\ n &= \text{dilution coefficient}\\ k &=\text{constant} \\ \Rightarrow \; \; t_{1}C_{1}^{n} &=t_{2}C_{2}^{n} \\ \text{in our case}\; n &=1 \\ \Rightarrow \; \; t_{1}C_{1}&=t_{2}C_{2} \\ t_{1} &=\frac{L}{v_{1}} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]L= \text{length of pipe}; [/latex] [latex]V_{1}=\text{velocity of flow}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} t_{1} &=\frac{L}{Q_{1}/A} \\ t_{1} &=\frac{L.A}{Q_{1}} \\ C_{1} &=\frac{W_{1}}{Q_{1}}, \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{where } W_{1} &=\text{weight of disinfectant per day}; \\ Q_{1}&=\text{discharge per day} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \; \; \frac{L.A}{Q_{1}}\times \frac{W_{1}}{Q_{1}} &=\frac{L.A}{Q_{2}}\times \frac{W_{2}}{Q_{2}} \\ \Rightarrow \; \; W_{2} &=\frac{Q_{2}^{2}}{Q_{1}^{2}}\times W_{1} \\ &=\left ( \frac{22}{16} \right )^{2}\times 32\; \text{kg/day} \\ &=60.5\; \text{kg/day} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 163 The amount of [latex]CO_{2}[/latex] generated (in kg) while completely oxidizing one kg of [latex]CH_{4}[/latex] to the end productsis ____________
solution: [latex]\mathrm{CH}_{4}+2 \mathrm{O}_{2} \rightarrow \mathrm{CO}_{2}+2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow\quad[/latex] 16 g of [latex]\mathrm{CH}_{4}[/latex] when completely oxidized leads to 44 g of [latex]\mathrm{CO}_{2} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow\quad [/latex]1 kg of [latex]\mathrm{CH}_{4}[/latex] when completely oxidized leads to [latex] \frac{44}{16} \times 1=2.75 \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{CO}_{2}[/latex]

question:
Question 166 A student began experiment for determination of 5-day, 20[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C BOD on Monday. Since the [latex]5^{th}[/latex] day
fell on Saturday, the final DO readings were taken on next Monday. On calculation, BOD (i.e. 7
day, 20[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C) was found to be 150 mg/L. What would be the 5-day, 20[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C BOD (in mg/L)? Assume
value of BOD rate constant (k) at standard temperature of 20[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C as 0.23/day (base e). __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} BOD_{7} &=L\left [ 1-e^{-k\times t} \right ] \\ \therefore \; \; 150 &=L\left [ 1-e^{-0.23\times 7} \right ] \\ \Rightarrow \; \; L &=187.54\: mg/L \\ \therefore \; \; BOD_{5} &=L\left [ 1-e^{-k\times t} \right ] \\ &=187.539\times \left [ 1-e^{-0.23\times 5} \right ] \\ &= 128.13\: mg/L \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 167 A settling tank in a water treatment plant is designed for a surface overflow rate of 30 [latex]\frac{m^{3}}{day\cdot m^{2}}[/latex]. Assume specific gravity of sediment particles = 2.65, density of water ([latex]\rho= 1000 kg/m^3[/latex]), dynamic viscosity of water ([latex]\mu=0.001 N.s/m^2[/latex]), and Stokes' law is valid. The approximate minimum size of particles that would be completely removed is:
solution: To calculate minimum size of particles equating setteling velocity to overflow rate, we get, [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{0} &=V_{s} \\ \Rightarrow\; \; V_{0} &=\frac{\left ( G_{s}-1 \right )\gamma _{W}d^{2}}{18\mu } \\ \text{Now }\; \; V_{0}&=\frac{30m^{2}}{day.m^{2}} \\ &=\frac{30}{24\times 60\times 60}\frac{m}{s} \\ \Rightarrow \;\; \frac{30}{24\times 60\times 60}&= \frac{\left ( 2.65-1 \right )\times 9.81\times 10^{3}\times d^{2}}{18\times 0.001}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Solving we get, [latex]d=1.965\times 10^{-5}\; m \approx 0.02\, mm[/latex]

Question 170 An activated sludge system (sketched below) is operating at equilibrium with the following information.
Wastewater related data:flow rate = 500 [latex]m^3[/latex]/hour, influent BOD = 150 mg/L, effluent BOD = 10 mg/L. Aeration tank related data: hydraulic retention time = 8 hours, mean-cell-residence time = 240 hours, volume = 4000 [latex]m^3[/latex], mixed liquor suspended solids = 2000 mg/L. The mass (in kg/day) of solids wasted from the system is
solution: Mean cell recidence time, [latex] \begin{aligned} \theta_{C} &=\frac{V X}{Q_{w} X_{u}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad Q_{W} X_{u} &=\frac{V X}{\theta_{C}}=\frac{4000 \times 2000 \times 10^{-3}}{10} \\ &=800 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{day} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 173 A water sample has a pH of 9.25. The concentration of hydroxyl ions in the water sample is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{H}} &=9.25 \\ \because\quad \mathrm{PH}+\mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{OH}} &=14 \\ \Rightarrow\quad \mathrm{p}^{OH} &=14-9.25=4.75 \\ \Rightarrow\quad -\log _{10}\left[\mathrm{OH}^{-}\right] &=4.75 \\ \therefore \quad [\mathrm{OH}] &=1.778 \times 10^{-5}\left(\frac{\mathrm{mol}}{\mathrm{lit}}\right) \\ \therefore \quad \frac{\mathrm{mol}}{\mathrm{lit}} \text { of } \mathrm{OH}^{-} &=1.778 \times 10^{-5} \\ \therefore \quad \frac{\mathrm{gm}}{\mathrm{lit}} \text { of } \mathrm{OH}^{-} &=1.778 \times 10^{-5} \times 17 \\ &=30.226 \times 10^{-5} \\ &=302.6 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{gm} / \mathrm{it} \\ \therefore \quad \left[\mathrm{OH}^{-}\right] &=302.6 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{lit} \\ &=0.302 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{lit} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 176 The sludge from the aeration tank of the activated sludge process (ASP) has solids
content (by weight) of 2%. This sludge is put in a sludge thickener, where sludge volume
is reduced to half. Assume that the amount of solids in the supernatant from the
thickener is negligible, the specific gravity of sludge solids is 2.2 and the density of water
is 1000 [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex]. What is the solids content (by weight) of the thickened sludge?
solution: Now, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{1} &=\text { Volume of sludge (initial) } \\ &=\text { Volume of solids }+\text { Volume of } w \\ &=\frac{2}{2.2 \times 1000}+\frac{98}{1000} \\ V_{1} &=0.0989 \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Volume of sludge after thickness [latex] \begin{aligned} &=V_{2}=\frac{V_{1}}{2} \\ V_{2} &=0.04945 \mathrm{m}^{3}\\ \therefore \quad 0.04945&= \text{ Vol. of solids }+\text{ Vol. of water}\\ \therefore \quad 0.04945&=\frac{2}{2.2 \times 1000}+\frac{x}{1000} \\ \therefore \quad x&=48.545 \% \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \text{ Solids content }(%\text{ by Wt.})[/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\frac{2}{2+48.545} \times 100 \\ =3.957 \% \\ \approx 3.96 \% \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 177 The sludge from the aeration tank of the activated sludge process (ASP) has solids
content (by weight) of 2%. This sludge is put in a sludge thickener, where sludge volume
is reduced to half. Assume that the amount of solids in the supernatant from the
thickener is negligible, the specific gravity of sludge solids is 2.2 and the density of water
is 1000 [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex]. What is the density of the sludge removed from the aeration tank?
solution: 2 % of solids +98 % water [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] 100 % of sludge let x be the density of sludge. [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \frac{100}{x}&=\frac{98}{1000}+\frac{2}{2.2 \times 1000} \\ &\quad \quad \ldots\text{ Harmonic mean }\\ \therefore \quad x&=1011 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{ms} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 178 Chlorine gas (8 mg/L as [latex]CI_2[/latex]) was added to a drinking water sample. If the free
chlorine residual and pH was measured to be 2mg/L (as [latex]CI_2[/latex]) and 7.5, respectively,
what is the concentration of residual [latex]OCI^{-} [/latex] ions in the water? Assume that the
chlorine gas added to the water is completely converted to HOCl and [latex]OCI^{-}[/latex]. 
Atomic Weight of Cl: 35.5 Given: [latex]OC1^{-}+H^{+}\leftrightharpoons^k HOCI, \; \; \; K=10^{7.5}[/latex]
solution: [latex]OCl^{-}\: +\: H^{+}\: \rightleftharpoons ^{K}\; \; HOCl;\; K=10^{7.5}[/latex] Now, [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{\left [ HOCl \right ]}{\left [ OCl^{-} \right ]\left [ H^{+} \right ]} &= K\\ pH&=7.5 \\ \left [ H^{+} \right ]&=10^{7.5} \\ \left [ \frac{HOCl}{OCl^{-}} \right ]&=10^{7.5}\times 10^{-7.5}=1 \\ \therefore \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \left [ HOCl \right ] &=\left [ OCl^{-} \right ] \\ \left [ \text{Free chlorine residual} \right ]&=\left [ HOCl \right ]+\left [ OCl^{-} \right ] \\ \text{Free chlorine residual} &= 2\; \text{mg/l}\\ \left [ \text{Free chlorine residual} \right ] &=\frac{2\times 10^{-3}}{Mol.\; wt\; of\; Cl_{2}} \\ &=\frac{2\times 10^{-3}}{2\times 35.5} \\ &=2.817\times 10^{-5}\; \text{moles/l} \\ \therefore \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; 2.817\times 10^{-5} &=\left [ HOCl \right ]+\left [ OCl^{-} \right ] \\ \therefore \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \left [ OCl^{-} \right ] &=\frac{2.817\times 10^{-5}}{2} \\ \because \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \left [ OCl^{-} \right ] &=\left [ HOCl \right ] \\ &=1.4084\times 10^{-5}\; \text{moles/l} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 179 Total suspended particulate matter (TSP) concentration in ambient air is to be
measured using a high volume sampler. The filter used for this purpose had an
initial dry weight of 9.787 g. The filter was mounted in the sampler and the initial
air flow rate through the filter was set at 1.5[latex]m^3[/latex]/min. Sampling continued for
24 hours. The airflow after 24 hours was measured to be 1.4 [latex]m^3[/latex]/min. The dry
weight of the filter paper after 24 hour sampling was 10.283 g. Assuming a linear
decline in the air flow rate during sampling, what is the 24 hour average TSP
concentration in the ambient air?
solution: Average airflow rate [latex]= 1.5-\left ( \frac{1.5-1.4}{24\times 60} \right )\times 12=1.45\; m^{3}/min[/latex] Total airflow through the sampler during 24 hours [latex] =1.45\times 24\times 60=2088\: m^{3}[/latex] TSP concentration in the ambient air [latex]=\left ( \frac{10.283-9.787}{2088} \right )\times 10^6=237.5\mu g/m^3[/latex]

question:
Question 180 In an aquifer extending over 150 hectare, the water table was 20m below ground
level. Over a period of time the water table dropped to 23m below the ground
level. If the porosity of aquifer is 0.40 and the specific retention is 0.15, what is
the change in ground water storage of the aquifer?
solution: We know that, [latex] \begin{aligned} n&=S_{y}+S_{r} \\ \Rightarrow\quad S_{y}&=S_{t}-n=0.15-0.40=-0.25 \end{aligned}[/latex] The negative sign signifies the decrease in storage. Change in volume of aquifer [latex] =150 \times(23-20)=450 \mathrm{ha}-\mathrm{m}[/latex] Specific yield is nothing but the actual volume of water that can be extracted by force of gravity from a unit volume of aquifer. [latex]\therefore [/latex]Change in water storage [latex] =450 \times 0.25=112.5 \mathrm{ha}-\mathrm{m}[/latex]

question: Question 181 Consider four common air pollutants found in urban environments, NO, [latex]SO_{2}[/latex], Soot and [latex]O_{3}[/latex]. Among these with one is the secondary air pollutant?
solution: Soot is a general term that refers to impure carbon particles resulting from the incomplete combustion of hydrocarbons. Soot, as an air borne contaminant in the environment has many different sources but they are all the result of some form of pyrolysis.

question: Question 182 Anaerobically treated effluent has MPN of total coliform as [latex]10^{6}[/latex]/100 mL. After chlorination, the MPN value declines to [latex]10^{2}[/latex]/100 mL. The percent removal (%R) and log removal (logR) of total coliform MPN is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \% R &=\left(\frac{10^{6}-10^{2}}{10^{6}}\right) \times 100 \\ &=0.9999 \times 100=99.99 \% \\ \log R &=\log 10^{6}-\log 10^{2}=6-2=4 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 184 Ion concentrations obtained for a groundwater sample (having pH=8.1) are given
below. Carbonate hardness (mg/L as [latex]CaCO_3[/latex]) present in the above water sample is
solution: Total alkalinity in water consists of alkalinity caused by [latex]\mathrm{CO}_{3}^{2-}, \mathrm{HCO}_{3}\text{ and }\mathrm{OH}^{-}.[/latex] A little negative alkalinity is also caused by [latex]\mathrm{H}^{+} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \text { Total Alkalinity } &=\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right] \times \frac{\mathrm{Eq} \cdot \mathrm{wt} . \text { of } \mathrm{CaCO}_{3}}{\mathrm{Eq}, \mathrm{wt} . \text { of } \mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}} \\ &=250 \times \frac{50}{61}=205 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{L} \end{aligned}[/latex] Carbonate hardness is equal to the total hardness or alkalinity, whichever is less. The carbonate hardness of the sample will be [latex]205 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{L} [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Non-carbonate hardness = Total hardness - carbonate hardness [latex] =275-205=70 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{L}[/latex]

question:
Question 185 Ion concentrations obtained for a groundwater sample (having pH=8.1) are given
below. Total hardness (mg/L as [latex]CaCO_3[/latex]) present in the above water sample is
solution: Total hardness [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\left[\mathrm{Mg}^{2+}\right] \times \frac{\mathrm{eq} \cdot \mathrm{wt} . \text { of } \mathrm{CaCO}_{3}}{\mathrm{eq} \cdot \mathrm{wt} \cdot \mathrm{of} \mathrm{Mg}^{2+}} \\ &\qquad +\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}\right] \times \frac{\mathrm{eq} . \mathrm{wt} . \text { of } \mathrm{CaCO}_{3}}{\text { eq. wh. of } \mathrm{Ca}^{2+}} \\ &=6 \times \frac{50}{12}+100 \times \frac{50}{20}=275 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{L} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 186 If the [latex]{BOD}_3[/latex] of a wastewater sample is 75mg/L and reaction rate constant k
(base e) is 0.345 per day, the amount of BOD remaining in the given sample after
10 days is
solution: The BOD at any instant is given by, [latex]\begin{aligned} L_{t} &=L\left [ 1-e^{-kt} \right ] \\ \Rightarrow \; \;75&=L\left [ 1-e^{-0.345} \right ] \\ \Rightarrow \; \; L&=\frac{75}{1-0.355} \\ \Rightarrow \; \; L &=116.32\: mg/l \end{aligned}[/latex] BOD after 10 days, [latex]\begin{aligned} L_{10} &=L\left [ 1-e^{-0.345\times 10} \right ] \\ &=116.32\times 0.968 \\ &=112.63\: mg/l \end{aligned}[/latex] Amount of BOD remaining =[latex]L-L_{0}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} &=116.32-112.63 \\ &=3.69\: mg/l \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 187 A well of diameter 20 cm fully penetrates a confined aquifer. After a long period
of pumping at rate of 2720 litres per minute, the observations of drawdown taken
at 10 m and 100 m distances from the centre of the well are found to be 3m and
0.5m respectively. The transmissivity of the aquifer is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q &=\frac{2 \pi T\left(s_{1}-s_{2}\right)}{\ln \left(\frac{r_{2}}{r_{1}}\right)} \\ T &=\frac{2720 \times 10^{-3} \times 24 \times 60 \times \ln \left(\frac{100}{10}\right)}{2 \times \pi \times(3-0.5)} \\ &=574.26 \mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{day} \simeq 576 \mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{day} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 188 An air parcel having 40[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C temperature moves from ground level to 500 m elevation in dry air following the "adiabatic lapse rate". The resulting temperature of air parcel at 500m elevation will be
solution: Dry air cools at the rate of [latex]9.8^{\circ}C[/latex] per km and it is called dry adiabatic lapse rate. In saturated (wet) air, this rate is calculated to be [latex]6^{\circ}C[/latex] per km and is known as wet adiabatic lapse rate. Resulting temperature of air [latex]=40-9.8\times \frac{500}{1000}=40-4.9=35.1^{\circ}C[/latex]

Question 190 A coastal city produces municipal solid waste (MSW) with high moisture content,
high organic materials, low calorific value and low inorganic materials. The most
effective and sustainable option for MSW management in that city is
solution: Incineration can be adopted when the calorific value of the MSW is high. Land fill can be adopted when the density of MSW is high. Barging the MSW into the sea is now a days generaly not used and has become obsolete.

solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &\text { Total Hardness in } \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{L} \text { as } \mathrm{CaCO}_{3} \\ &=\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}\right] \times \mathrm{Combining} \text { weight of } \mathrm{CaCO}_{3}+\left[\mathrm{Mg}^{2+}\right]\\ &\times \text { combining weight of } \mathrm{CaCO}_{3} \\ &= 12 \times 50+18 \times 50=600+900=1500 \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 194 An aerobic reactor receives wastewater at a flow rate of 500 [latex]m^{3}/d[/latex] having a COD of 2000 mg/L. The effluent COD is 400 mg/L. Assuming that wastewater contains
80% biodegradable waste, the daily volume of methane produced by the reactor is
solution: Organic matter stabilized per day [latex] \begin{aligned} & =Q\left[S_{i}-S_{o}\right] \times \eta \\ & =500 \times 10^{3}(2000-400) \times 0.8 \\ & =640 \mathrm{kg} \\ & \therefore 1 \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{BOD}\text{ generates } 0.35 \mathrm{m}^{3} methane\\ & \therefore 640 \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{BOD} \text{ generates }0.35 \times 640=224 \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 195 A horizontal flow primary clarifier treats wastewater in which 10%, 60% and 30% of particles have settling velocities of 0.1 mm/s, 0.2 mm/s and 0.1 mm/s
respectively. What would be the total percentage of particles removed if clarifier
operates at a Surface Overflow Rate (SOR) of 43.2 [latex]m^{3}/m^{2}.d[/latex] ?
solution: Surface overflow rate [latex]\begin{aligned} &=43.2\; m^{3}/m^{2}-d=43.2\; \text{m/d} \\ &=\frac{43.2\times 10^{3}}{24\times 60\times 60}\; \text{mm/s} \\ &=0.5\; \text{mm/s} \end{aligned}[/latex] It means that particles which have setting velocities more than surface overflow rate will be 100% removed. [latex]\therefore[/latex] Total percentage of particles removed [latex]\begin{aligned} &=30+60\times \frac{0.2}{0.5}+10\times \frac{0.1}{0.5} \\ &=30+24=2=56\% \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 201 A water treatment plant is required to process 28800 [latex]m^{3}/d[/latex] of raw water
(density=1000 kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex], kinematic viscosity= [latex]10^{-6}m^{2}/s[/latex]). The rapid mixing tank imparts a velocity gradient of [latex]900s^{-1}[/latex] to blend 35 mg/l of alum with the flow for a detention time of 2 minutes. The power input (W) required for rapid mixing is
solution: The power input (W) required for rapid mixing is expressed in terms of temporal mean velocity gradient, G, expressed by the equation, [latex]G=\left [ \frac{P}{\mu V} \right ]^{1/2}\; \; \; \; \; \Rightarrow \; \; \; \; \; P=G^{2}\mu V[/latex] where [latex]\mu[/latex]=dynamic viscosity of raw water [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\text{kinematic viscosity}\times \text{density} \\ &=10^{-6}\times 10^{3}=10^{-3}\; \text{N-s}/m^{2} \\ \text{G} &=900\; s^{-} \\ \text{t}&=2\; \text{minutes}=120\; \text{seconds} \end{aligned}[/latex] Discharge of raw water [latex]\; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; =\frac{28800}{24\times 60\times 60}=0.33\; m^{3}/s[/latex] Volume of water in tank, [latex]\; \; \; \; \; \; V=0.33\times 120=40\; m^{3}[/latex] [latex]\therefore \; \; \; \; \; P=\left ( 900 \right )^{2}\times 10^{-3}\times 40[/latex] [latex]\; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; =32400\;[/latex]watts

question: Question 202 The 5-day BOD of a wastewater sample is obtained as 190 mg/l (with k = 0.01[latex]h^{-1}[/latex]). The ultimate oxygen demand (mg/l) of the sample will be

Question 205 A wastewater sample contains [latex]10^{-5.6}[/latex] mmol/l of [latex]OH^{-}[/latex]
 ions at 25[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. The pH of this sample is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{pOH} &=-\log \left[\mathrm{OH}^{-}\right] \\ \Rightarrow\quad \mathrm{pOH} &=-\log \left(10^{-5.6} \times 10^{-3}\right) \\ \Rightarrow\quad \mathrm{pOH} &=-\log \left(10^{-8.6}\right) \\ \mathrm{pOH}&=8.6\\ \text{BH}\quad \mathrm{pH}+\mathrm{pOH} &=14 \\ \Rightarrow\quad \mathrm{pH} &=14-8.6 \\ \Rightarrow\quad \mathrm{pH} &=5.4 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 206 A volume of [latex]3.0 \times 10^{6} m^{3}[/latex] of groundwater was pumped form an unconfined aquifer uniformly from an area of 5 [latex]km^{2}[/latex]. The pumping lowered the water table form initial level of 102 m to 99 m. The specific yield of the aquifer is
solution: Specific yield [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\frac{\begin{array}{c} \text{Volume of water pumped }\\\text { out of the aquifer }\end{array}}{\text { Total volume of aquifer }} \\ &=\frac{3.0 \times 10^{6}}{5 \times 10^{6} \times(102-99)}=0.20 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 208 Two primary air pollutants are

question:
Question 209 A plain sedimentation tank with a length of 20 m, width of 10 m, and a depth of
3 m is used in a water treatment plant to treat 4 million litres of water per day
(4 MLD). The average temperature of water is 20[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. The dynamic viscosity of
water is [latex]1.002 \times 10^{-3}N.s/m^2[/latex] at 20[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. Density of water is 998.2 [latex]kg/m^3[/latex]. Average
specific gravity of particles is 2.65. What is the minimum diameter of the particle which can be removed with 100%
efficiency in the above sedimentation tank ?
solution: Settling velocity, [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{s} &=\frac{H}{t} \\ \text{But} \; \; \; \; \; \; \; t&=\frac{Volume\; of\; tank}{Rate\; of\; flow} \\ &=\frac{20\times 10\times 3\times 24\times 60\times 60}{4\times 10^{6}\times 10^{-3}} \\ &=12960\; \text {seconds} \\ \therefore \; \; \; \; \; \; \; V_{s} &=\frac{3\times 1000}{12960}=0.2315\; \text{mm/s} \end{aligned}[/latex] Let the velocity of the particle which can be removed with 100% efficiency be [latex]{V}'_{s}[/latex] then [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{{V}'_{s}}{V_{s}}\times 100 &=100 \\ \Rightarrow {V}'_{s} &=V_{s} \\ \frac{g}{18}\left ( S_{s}-1 \right )\frac{d^{2}\rho }{\mu } &=0.2315\times 10^{-3} \\ \frac{9.81}{18}\left ( 2.65-1 \right )d^{2}\times \frac{998.2}{1.002\times 10^{-3}} &=0.2315\times 10^{-3} \\ d^{2}&=2.58\times 10^{-10} \\ d &=1.6\times 10^{-5}\text{m} \\ &=16\times 10^{-3}\text{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 211 A completely mixed activated sludge process is used to treat a wastewater flow
of 1 million litres per day (1 MLD) having a [latex]BOD_5[/latex] of 200 mg/L. The biomass
concentration in the aeration tank is 2000 mg/L and the concentration of the net
biomass leaving the system is 50 mg/L. The aeration tank has a volume of 200 [latex]m^3[/latex]. What is the average time for which the biomass stays in the system ?
solution: The average time for which the biomass stays in the system is known as sludge age [latex]\left(\theta_{\mathrm{c}}\right)[/latex] and it is given by, [latex] \theta_{c}=\frac{\text { Mass of biomass in the system }}{\text { Mass of biomass leaving the system per day }} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \theta_{c}=\frac{200 \times 10^{3} \times 2000}{50 \times 10^{6}} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \theta_{c}=8 \text{days}[/latex]

question:
Question 212 A completely mixed activated sludge process is used to treat a wastewater flow
of 1 million litres per day (1 MLD) having a [latex]BOD_5[/latex] of 200 mg/L. The biomass
concentration in the aeration tank is 2000 mg/L and the concentration of the net
biomass leaving the system is 50 mg/L. The aeration tank has a volume of 200 [latex]m^3[/latex]. What is the hydraulic retention time of the wastewater in aeration tank ?
solution: The hydraulic retention time is given by, [latex] t=\frac{V}{Q} \times 24[/latex] where V= Volume of aeration tank Q= Quantity of waste water flow into the aeration tank excluding the quantity of recycled sludge [latex] \therefore \quad t=\frac{200}{1 \times 10^{6} \times 10^{-3}} \times 24=4.8 \mathrm{h}[/latex]

question: Question 213 50 g of [latex]CO_{2}[/latex] and 25 g of [latex]CH_{4}[/latex] are produced from the decomposition of municipal solid waste (MSW) with a formula weight of 120 g. What is the average per capita green house gas production in a city of 1 million people with a MSW production rate of 500 ton/day ?
solution: We know that both [latex]CO_{2}[/latex] and [latex]CH_{4}[/latex] are green house gases. [latex]\therefore[/latex] Total green house gases produced by 120 gm of MSW = 50 g [latex]CO_{2}[/latex] +25 g of [latex]CH_{4}[/latex]=75 gm 500 ton of MSW will produce green house gases [latex]\begin{aligned} &=500\times 10^{6}\times \frac{75}{120} \\ &= 312.5\times 10^{6}\: g/day \end{aligned}[/latex] Per capita average production of green house gases [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\frac{312.5\times 10^{6}}{1\times 10^{6}}\: g/day \\ &=312.5\: g/day\approx 313\: g/day \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 214 Two electrostatic precipitators (ESPs) are in series. The fractional efficiencies of
the upstream and downstream ESPs for size [latex]d_{p}[/latex]
 are 80% and 65%, respectively.
What is the overall efficiency of the system for the same [latex]d_{p}[/latex] ?
solution: Given data:  [latex]\eta _{1}=80%;\; \; \eta _{2}=65%[/latex] Since the efficiency of upstream ESP is 80%, only 20% of the particulate are not removed. These remaining particulates will face the downstream ESP whose efficiency is 65%. [latex]\therefore[/latex] Particulates removed by downstream, [latex] ESP=20\times \frac{65}{100}=13\%[/latex] The two ESPs are connected in series, therefore the overall efficiency = 80 + 13 = 93%.

question: Question 216 The dispersion of pollutants in atmosphere is maximum when
solution: When the environment lapse rate is more than the adiabatic lapse rate, a rising parcel of warm lighter air (pollutants) will continue to lift up; where as a parcel of heavier cooler air will continue to come down. In such circumstances the environment is unstable and the dispersion of pollutants will be rapid due to marked vertical mixing of the air.

options.A: environment lapse rate is greater than adiabatic lapse rate
options.B: environment lapse rate is less than adiabatic lapse rate
options.C: environment lapse rate is equal to adiabatic lapse rate
options.D: maximum mixing depth is equal to zero

Question 218 A water sample contains the following dissolved ions. [latex][Na^+][/latex]= 56mg/L; [latex][Ca^{2+}][/latex]=40 mg/L; [latex][Mg^{2+}][/latex]=30mg/L [latex][AI^{3+}][/latex]=3 mg/L; [latex][HCO^{-}_{3}][/latex]=190mg/L; [latex][CI^{-}][/latex]=165mg/L; Water pH is 7. Atomic weights: Ca:40; Mg:24; Al:27; H:1; C:12; O:16; Na:23; Cl:35.5 The non-carbonate hardness of the sample in mg/L as [latex]CaCO_{3}[/latex] is
solution: Carbonate hardness [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\left[H C O_{3}\right] \times \frac{e q \cdot w t \cdot \text { of } C a C O_{3}}{e q \cdot w t \cdot \text { of } H C O_{3}^{-}}=190 \times \frac{50}{61} \\ &=155.74 \simeq 156 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{L} as \mathrm{CaCO}_{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Noncarbonate hardness = Total hardness - Carbonate hardness [latex] =242-156=86 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{L} \text { as } \mathrm{CaCO}_{3}[/latex]

question: Question 219 A water sample contains the following dissolved ions. [latex][Na^+][/latex]= 56mg/L; [latex][Ca^{2+}][/latex]=40 mg/L; [latex][Mg^{2+}][/latex]=30mg/L [latex][AI^{3+}][/latex]=3 mg/L; [latex][HCO^{-}_{3}][/latex]=190mg/L; [latex][CI^{-}][/latex]=165mg/L; Water pH is 7. Atomic weights: Ca:40; Mg:24; Al:27; H:1; C:12; O:16; Na:23; Cl:35.5 The total hardness of the sample in mg/L as [latex]CaCO_{3}[/latex] is
solution: Total hardness [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\left[M g^{2+}\right] \times \frac{e q \cdot w t \cdot o f C a C O_{3}}{e q \cdot w t \cdot o f M g^{2+}}+\left[C a^{2+}\right] \\ &\times \frac{\text { eq. wt. of } \mathrm{CaCO}_{3}}{\text { eq. wt. of } \mathrm{Ca}^{2+}}+\left[\mathrm{A} l^{+3}\right] \times \frac{50}{9} \\ &=\left(30 \times \frac{50}{12}\right)+\left(40 \times \frac{50}{20}\right)+3 \times \frac{50}{9} \\ &=242 \text{ in } \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{L} \text{ as }\mathrm{CaCO}_{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

of the effluent from the filter is greater than 2.5 NTU. The time for reaching

run to the time when head loss across the filter is greater than 3 m. The effect of increasing the filter loading rate (while keeping all other conditions
same) on [latex]T_{B}[/latex] and [latex]T_H[/latex] is

Question 221 In a rapid sand filter, the time for reaching particle break through ([latex]T_B[/latex]) is defined
as the time elapsed from start of filter run to the time at which the turbidity
of the effluent from the filter is greater than 2.5 NTU. The time for reaching
terminal head loss ([latex]T_H[/latex]) is defined as the time elapsed from the start of the filter
run to the time when head loss across the filter is greater than 3 m. The effect of increasing the filter depth (while keeping all other conditions same) on [latex]T_{B}[/latex] and [latex]T_{H}[/latex] is
solution: The effect of increase in certain rapid sand filter and influent particle characteristics on time ([latex]T_{B}[/latex]) for reaching particle breakthrough (turbidity [latex] \gt[/latex] 2.5 NTU) in the effluent, and time ([latex]T_{H}[/latex]) of reaching terminal head-loss([latex] \gt[/latex] 3 m) across filter bed are given below. Explain the results based on you understanding of filter operation and particle removal mechanisms operative in rapid sand filters. Assume that when one characteristic is changed, all other characteristic remain fixed. Effect of increase in filter depth (L) [latex]T_{B}[/latex] : [latex]T_{B}[/latex] will increase since particles in water will have the opportunity to potentially interact with more collectors, and hence the change for particle attachment to a collector is more. [latex]T_{H}[/latex]: Since bed depth is more, water is encounter more resistance is passing through the bed. Hence [latex]T_{H}[/latex] will decrease. Effect of increase in superdicial velocity ([latex]V_{s}[/latex]) [latex]T_{B}[/latex]: Since pore velocity is more, the shear forces experianced by collected particles will be more. Hence particle detachment will be more, leading to a decrease in [latex]T_{B}[/latex]. [latex]T_{H}[/latex]: Since particle loading rate on the filter and rate of particle collection in the filter will increase, the porosity of the filter bed will decrease more rapidly, leading to more rapid head-loss buildup and hence a decrease in [latex]T_{H}[/latex]. Effect of increase in influent particle concentration ([latex]C_{o}[/latex]) [latex]T_{B}[/latex]: Particle loading rate on the filter, rate of particle collection and hence porosity of the filter bed will decrease more rapidly. Thus pre velocity in the filter bed will increase more rapidly, leading to more rapid particle detachment. This will lead to decrease in [latex]T_{B}[/latex]. [latex]T_{H}[/latex]: Since particle loading rate on the filter and rate of particle collection in the filter will be increase, the porosity of the filter bed will decrease more rapidly, leading to more rapid head-loss buildup and hence a decrease in [latex]T_{H}[/latex]. Effect of increase in floc strength [latex]T_{B}[/latex]: Particle detachment due to shear force will become less prominent leading to increase in [latex]T_{B}[/latex]. [latex]T_{H}[/latex]: Since particle retention in the filter will be more, the porosity of the filter bed will decline faster leading to faster buildup of head-loss and hence [latex]T_{H}[/latex] will decrease. Effect of increase in collector diameter (d) [latex]T_{B}[/latex]: Increase in collector diameter will mean the presence of a lesser number of collector in the filter media. This will result is lesser number of potential interaction between a particle and a collector. Thus [latex]T_{B}[/latex] is expected to decrease. [latex]T_{H}[/latex]: Since lesser number of particle will be collected as mentioned above, the rate of head-loss buildup will be lower, leading to increase in [latex]T_{H}[/latex]. Effect of increase in porosity ([latex]\alpha [/latex]) It must be realized that the porosity of the filter media does not depend on particle size, but on grading of particles. Well-graded sand, i.e., with a broader particle size distribution will have less porosity, as compared to poorly graded sand with a narrower particle size distribution. [latex]T_{B}[/latex] : In case poorly graded sand (with more porosity) is used as the filter media, the influent particles will potentially encounter lesser number of collectors and will not be collected efficiently.Hence [latex]T_{B}[/latex] will decrease. [latex]T_{H}[/latex]: Increase in porosity of sand and poor particle collection as described above will result in lower rate of head-loss buildup and hence increase in [latex]T_{H}[/latex]. Effect of non-addition of coagulant [latex]T_{B}[/latex]: If no coagulants are added, the particles will be stable and hence will not attach efficiently to the filter media. Hence [latex]T_{B}[/latex] will decrease. [latex]T_{H}[/latex]: Since rate of particle clollection in the filter media will be lower as described above, the rate of head-loss buildup will also be lower, leading to an increase in [latex]T_{H}[/latex].

components are given below : Specific weight ([latex]kg/m^3[/latex]) of the MSW sample is
solution: Let specific weight of MSW sample is X kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Now,} \; \; \rho &= \frac{Total\; weight}{Total\; volume}\\ \frac{100}{X}&=\frac{50}{300}+\frac{30}{500}+\frac{10}{65}+\frac{10}{125} \\ \therefore \; \;\frac{100}{X} &=0.4605 \\ \therefore \;\; X &=217.15\; kg/m^{3}\approx 217\: kg/m^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 223 The mean indoor airborne Chloroform ([latex]CHCI_3[/latex]) concentration in a room was
determine to be 0.4[latex] \mu g/m^{3}[/latex]. 
Use the following data : T = 293 K, P = 1 atmosphere, R =[latex] 82.05\times 10^{-6} atm.m^{3}[/latex]/mol-K, Atomic weight : C=12, H=1, Cl=35.5. This concentration expressed in parts per billion (volume basis, ppbv) is equal to
solution: The relation between [latex]\mu g/m^{3}[/latex] and ppm is, [latex]1\mu g/m^{3}=\frac{1\: ppm \times \text{ molecular mass of pollutant in g/mol } }{\text{L/mol of pollutant at given temp. and pressure} \left ( V_{2} \right )} \times 10^3 \; L/m^3[/latex] By Avogadro's law, we known that, [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{P_{1}V_{1}}{T_{1}}&= \frac{P_{2}V_{2}}{T_{2}}\\ \text{where }\; P_{1} &=1\text{atmosphere;} \\ T_{1} &=0^{\circ}C=273 \text{K} \\ V_{1} &=\text{volume at }0^{\circ}C \text{at 1 atmosphere} \\ &=22.4\: L/mol \\ \text{Given}\: P_{2} &=1\: \text{atmosphere}; \\ T_{2} &=293\text{K} \\ \therefore \; \; V_{2} &=\frac{P_{1}V_{1}T_{2}}{P_{2}T_{1}} \\ V_{2}&=\frac{22.4\times 293}{273} \\ V_{2} &=24.04\; L/mol \\ \because \; \; \; 0.4\; \mu \mu g/m^{3}\: \text{of}CHCl_{3} &=\frac{CHCl_{3}\; in\; ppm\times 119.5\times 10^{3}}{24.04} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; \; \; CHCl_{3}[/latex] in ppm [latex]=8.0469\times 10^{-5}[/latex] [latex] CHCl_{3}[/latex] in ppbv [latex]=8.0469\times 10^{-5}\times 10^{3} =0.08\; ppbv[/latex]

Question 224 A synthetic sample of water is prepared by adding 100 mg Kaolinite (a clay mineral), 200 mg glucose, 168 mg NaCl, 120 mg [latex]MgSO_{4}[/latex] , and 111 mg [latex]CaCL_{2}[/latex] to
1 litre of pure water. The concentrations of total solids (TS) and fixed dissolved
solids (FDS) respectively in the solution in mg/L are equal to

question: Question 225 The cumulative noise power distribution curve at a certain location is given below The value of [latex]L_{40}[/latex] is equal to

question:
Question 226 To determine the [latex]BOD_{5}[/latex]
 of a waste water sample, 5, 10 and 50 mL aliquots of the
waste water were dilute to 300 mL and incubated at 20[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C in BOD bottles for 5
days. The results were as follows Based on the data, the average [latex]BOD_{5}[/latex] of the waste water is equal to
solution: For sample number-3: DO after 5 days= 0 mg/l Hence this data is to be neglected as nothing can be determined from this test. Sample-1: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{BOD} &=\left ( DO_{i}-DO_{f} \right )\times \text{dilution factor} \\ &=\left ( 9.2-6.9 \right )\times \frac{300}{5} \\ &= 138\: mg/l \end{aligned}[/latex] Sample-2: [latex]BOD=\left ( 9.1-4.4 \right )\times \frac{300}{10}=141\: mg/l[/latex] Sample-3: Final DO is zero, this shows that dilution is not sufficient for this sample. This final DO might have been zero before 5 days so we will discard this sample result. Average BOD=139.5 mg/l

Question 228 A city is going to install the rapid sand filter after the sedimentation tanks. Use
the following data. Design loading rate to the filter : 200[latex]m^{3}/m^2/d[/latex] Design flow rate : 0.5[latex]m^{3}/s[/latex] Surface area per filter box : 50[latex]m^{2}[/latex] The number of filters required shall be
solution: Number of filters [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\frac{\text{Total surface area}}{\text{Surface area of each filter box}} \\ &=\frac{216}{50}=4.32\simeq 5 \end{aligned}[/latex] As per the option select 6 filters.

question:
Question 229 A city is going to install the rapid sand filter after the sedimentation tanks. Use
the following data. Design loading rate to the filter : 200[latex]m^{3}/m^2/d[/latex] Design flow rate : 0.5[latex]m^{3}/s[/latex] Surface area per filter box : 50[latex]m^{2}[/latex] The surface area required for the rapid sand filter will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Total surface area} &=\frac{\text{Design flow rate}}{\text{Design loading rate}} \\ &=\frac{0.5}{200/\left ( 24\times 60\times 60 \right )} \\ &=\frac{24\times 60\times 60\times 0.5}{200} \\ &=216\; m^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 230 A circular primary clarifier processes an average flow of 5005 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/d of municipal waste water. The overflow rate is 35 [latex]m^{3}/m^{2}[/latex]/d. The diameter of clarifier shall be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Area of clarifier} &=\frac{\text{Average flow of waste water}}{\text{Overflow rate}} \\ &=\frac{5005}{35}=143\; m^{2} \\ \therefore \; \; \frac{\pi }{4}D^{2} &=143 \\ \Rightarrow \; \; D^{2} &=\frac{143\times 4}{\pi } \\ \Rightarrow \; \; D &=13.5\; \text{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 231 In a certain situation, waste water discharged into a river mixer with the river
water instantaneously and completely. Following is the data available : Waste water: DO = 2.00 mg/L Discharge rate = 1.10 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/s River water: DO = 8.3 mg/L Flow rate = 8.70 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/s Temperature = 20[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C Initial amount of DO in the mixture of waste and river shall be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} DO_{mix} &=\frac{Q_{W}DO_{W}+Q_{R}DO_{R}}{Q_{W}+Q_{R}} \\ &=\frac{\left ( 1.10\times 2.00 \right )+\left ( 8.70\times 8.3 \right )}{1.10+8.70} \\ &=7.6\: mg/L \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 241 Chlorine gas used for disinfection combines with water to form hypochlorous acid (HOCl). The HOCl ionizes to form hypochlorite [latex]\left (OCL^{-} \right )[/latex] in a reversible reaction : [latex]HOCI \rightleftharpoons H^{+}+OCl^{-} [/latex] [latex](k=2.7\times 10^{-8} \; at\; 20^{\circ}C)[/latex], the equilibrium of which is government by pH. The sum of HOCl and [latex]OCL^{-}[/latex] is known as free chlorine residual and HOCl is the more effective disinfectant. The 90% fraction of HOCI in the free chlorine residual is available at a pH value
solution: [latex]HOCI\rightleftharpoons H^{+}+OCI^{-}[/latex] The above reaction is a reversible reaction. The formation of end products depends upon the pH value of water. Reaction will be in forward direction if pH [latex]\gt[/latex] 8 i.e. more [latex]OCI^{-}[/latex] ions will be formed. if pH [latex]\lt[/latex] 7 (more than 5), then more of HOCI will be formed. It may be noted that pH should not be less than 5 because [latex]CI_{2}[/latex] do not react with water when pH [latex]\lt[/latex] 5

question:
Question 242 The design parameter for flocculation is given by a dimensionless number Gt,
where G is the velocity gradient and t is the detention time. Values of Gt ranging
from [latex]10^{4} \; to \; 10^{5}[/latex] are commonly used, with t ranging from 10 to 30 min. The most preferred combination of G and t to produce smaller and denser flocs is
solution: Large G value with short times tend to produce small, dense flocs, while low G values and long times produce larger, lighter flocs. Since larger, dense flocs are more easily removed in the setting basin, it may be advantageous to vary the G values over the length of the flocculation basin. The small dense flocs produced at high G values subsequently combine into larger flocs at the lower G values. Reduction in G values by a factor of 2 from the influent end to the effluent end of the flocculator has been shown to be effective.

options.A: large G values with short t
options.B: large G values with long t
options.C: smaller G values with short t
options.D: small G values with long  t

question:
Question 243 The following data are given for a channel-type grit chamber of length 7.5 m. 1. flow-through velocity = 0.3 m/s 2. the depth of waste water at peak flow in the channel = 0.9 m 3. specific gravity of inorganic particles = 2.5 4. g = 9.80 m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex], m=[latex]1.002 \times 10^{-3} N-s/m^{2}[/latex] at 20[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C, 
[latex]\rho _{w}=1000 kg/m^{3}[/latex] Assuming that the Stoke's law is valid, the largest diameter particles that would
be removed with 100 percent efficiency is
solution: Flow through velocity, [latex]V=\frac{Q}{B H} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad \frac{Q}{B} &=V \times H \\ &=0.3 \times 0.9=0.27 \mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned} [/latex] Settling velocity, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{s}&=\frac{Q}{B L}=\frac{0.27}{7.5}=0.036 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ \text{But, }\quad V_{s}&=\frac{\rho_{w} g}{18}\left(\frac{S_{s}-1}{\mu}\right) \mathrm{d}^{2}=0.036 \\ \Rightarrow \quad d^{2}&=\frac{0.036 \times \mu \times 18}{\rho_{w} \times g \times\left(S_{s}-1\right)} \\ \Rightarrow \quad d^{2}&=\frac{0.036 \times 1.002 \times 10^{-3} \times 18}{1000 \times 9.81 \times(2.5-1)} \\ \Rightarrow \quad d^{2}&=4.42 \times 10^{-8} \\ \therefore \quad d&=2.10 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{m}=0.21 \mathrm{mm} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 247 An analysis for determination of solids in the return sludge of Activated Sludge Process was done as follows: 1.) A crucible was dried to a constant mass of 62.485 g. 2.) 75 mL of a well-mixed sample was taken in the crucible. 3.) The crucible with the sample was dried to a constant mass of 65.020 g in a drying oven at [latex]104^{\circ}C[/latex]. 4.) The crucible with the dried sample was placed in a muffle furnace at [latex]600^{\circ}C[/latex], for an hour. After cooling, the mass of the crucible with residues was 63.145 g. The concentration of organic fraction of solids present in the return sludge sample
is
solution: Weight of sample of [latex]104^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=65.02 \mathrm{g} [/latex] Weight of samle at [latex]600^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=63.145 \mathrm{g} [/latex] Note: Organic matter will get converted into carbon idoxide, water vapour and other gases at [latex] 600^{\circ} [/latex] Concentration of organic fraction of solids [latex] =\frac{\text { Weight of organic fraction }}{\text { Volume of sample }} [/latex] [latex] =\frac{65.02-63.145}{75} \times \frac{10^{3}}{10^{-3}}=25000 \mathrm{mg} / l[/latex]

question:
Question 248 An existing 300 mm diameter circular sewer is laid at a slope of 1:28 and carries
a peak discharge of 1728 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/d. Use the partial flow diagram shown in the given figure and assume Manning's n = 0.015 At the peak discharge, the depth of flow and the velocity are, respectively
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q &=\left ( \frac{\pi }{4}D^{2} \right ).\frac{R^{\frac{2}{3}}S^{\frac{1}{2}}}{n}\; \; \; \; \; \left [ R=D/4 \right ] \\ &=\frac{\pi }{4}\times 0.3^{2}\times \left ( \frac{0.3}{4} \right )^{2/3}\times \frac{\sqrt{1/280}}{0.015} \\ &=0.05\: m^{3}/d \\ Q&=4327.3\: m^{3}/d \\ q&=1728\: m^{3}/d \\ \therefore \frac{q}{Q} &= 0.4 \end{aligned}[/latex] From graph, [latex]\frac{d}{D}=0.4\; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \therefore \; \; d=120\; mm[/latex] From graph, [latex]\frac{v}{V}=0.4[/latex] [latex]\therefore \; \; \; \; v=0.7\times \frac{1}{n}R^{2/3}\: S^{1/2}[/latex] [latex]=0.496\: m/s\approx 0.5\: m/s[/latex]

question: Question 249 The present population of a community is 28000 with an average water consumption of 4200 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/d. The existing water treatment plant has a design capacity of 6000 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/d. It is expected that the population will increase to 44000 during the next 20 years. The number of years from now when the plant will reach its design capacity, assuming an arithmetic rate of population growth, will be
solution: Assuming arithmetic rate of growth of population. Increase in population per year [latex] =\frac{44000-28000}{20}=800[/latex] Discharge required to reach design capacity [latex] =6000-4200=1800 m^{3} / d[/latex] Present average water consumption per head per day [latex] =\frac{4200}{28000}=0.15 \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] Increase in water consumption each year [latex] =0.15 \times 800=120 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{day}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] No. of years required to reach design capacity [latex] =\frac{1800}{120}=15 \text { years }[/latex]

question:
Question 253 A water treatment plant treating 10 MLD of water requires 20 mg/L of filter
Alum, [latex]AI_2(SO_4)_3.18H_2O[/latex]. The water has 6 mg/L of alkalinity as [latex]CaCO_3[/latex] (Al = 26.97, S = 32, O = 16, H = 1, Ca = 40 and C = 12). Quantity of Quick Lime required ( [latex]10^{6}[/latex] mg per year as CaO) shall be
solution: Natural alkalinity available in water =6 mg /L Total alkalinity required to be added in the form [latex] \text { of quick lime }=9-6=3 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{L} [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{cccc} &\mathrm{CaCO}_{3} &\longrightarrow &\mathrm{CaO}+\mathrm{CO}_{2} \\ &100 \mathrm{gm} &\quad &56 \mathrm{gm} \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \therefore 56 \mathrm{gm} [/latex] of CaO (quick lime) is required to produce [latex] 100 \mathrm{gm} of \mathrm{CaCO}_{3} [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Quantity of CaO required [latex] =\frac{56}{100} \times 3 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{L}=1.68 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{L}[/latex] Total amount of CaO required [latex] \begin{aligned} &=10 \times 10^{6} \times 1.68 \times 365 \\ &=6132 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{mg} \text { per year } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 254 A water treatment plant treating 10 MLD of water requires 20 mg/L of filter
Alum, [latex]AI_2(SO_4)_3.18H_2O[/latex]. The water has 6 mg/L of alkalinity as [latex]CaCO_3[/latex] (Al = 26.97, S = 32, O = 16, H = 1, Ca = 40 and C = 12). Total alkalinity requirement ([latex]10^{6}[/latex] mg per day as [latex]CaCO_{3}[/latex]) matching filter Alum, shall be
solution: [latex]\left ( i \right )\; \; \begin{matrix} Al_{2}\left ( SO_{4} \right )_{3}.\: 18H_{2}O+3Ca\left ( HCO_{3} \right )_{2}\\ 666\; gm\; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \left ( 3\times 162 \right )gm \end{matrix}[/latex] [latex]\rightarrow 3CaSO_{4}+2Al\left ( OH \right )_{3}\downarrow+6CO_{2}\uparrow+18H_{2}O[/latex] [latex]\left ( ii \right )\begin{matrix} CaCO_{3}+H_{2}O+CO_{2}\rightarrow Ca\left ( HCO_{3} \right )_{2}\\ 100\: gm\; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; \; 162\: gm \end{matrix}[/latex] From (i) it is clear that 666 gm filter Alum can neutralize [latex]\left ( 3\times 162 \right )[/latex] gm of alkalinity as [latex]Ca\left ( HCO_{3} \right )_{2}[/latex]. Again from (ii) it is clear that this [latex]\left ( 3\times 162 \right )[/latex] gm of alkalinity as [latex]Ca\left ( HCO_{3} \right )_{2}[/latex] is equivalent to [latex]\left ( 3\times 100 \right )[/latex] gm of alkalinity as [latex]CaCO_{3}[/latex]. [latex]\therefore[/latex] Total alkalinity of filter alum as [latex]CaCO_{3}[/latex], for water requiring 20 mg/L of filter alum [latex]=\frac{3\times 100}{666}\times 20\; mg/L=9\; mg/L[/latex] Hence total alkalinity requirement [latex]\begin{aligned} &=10\times 10^{6}\times 9\: mg/day \\ &=90\times 10^{6}\; mg/day \end{aligned}[/latex]
