Question 257 An ideal horizontal flow settling basing is 3 m deep having surface area 900 [latex]m^{2}[/latex]. Water flows at the rate of 8000 [latex]m^{3}/d[/latex], at water temperature 20[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C (m=[latex]10^{-3}[/latex] kg/m.s and [latex]\rho =1000 kg/m^3[/latex]). Assuming Stoke's law to be valid, the proportion (percentage) of spherical sand particles (0.01 mm in diameter with specific gravity 2.65), that will be removed, is
solution: Velocity of sand particles, [latex]\begin{aligned} {V}'_{s} &=\frac{g}{18}\left ( S_{s}-1 \right )\frac{d^{2}}{\nu } \\ &=\frac{9.81}{18}\times \left ( 2.65-1 \right )\times \frac{\left ( 0.001\times 10^{-3} \right )^{2}}{\left ( 10^{-3}/1000 \right )} \\ &=\frac{9.81}{18}\times 1.65\times 10^{-4} \\ {V}'_{s} &=8.9925\times 10^{-5}\; \text{m/sec} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\text{settling time}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\frac{\text{Volume of tank}}{\text{Water flow rate}} \\ &=\frac{900\times 3}{8000}days=\frac{2700}{8000}\times 24=8.1\; hrs \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\text{Settling velocity,}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{s} &=\frac{\text{Depth of tank}}{\text{Settling time}}=\frac{3}{8.1\times 3600} \\ &=1.0288\times 10^{-4}\; \text{m/s} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\therefore \; \;\text{ Removal efficiency}=\frac{{V}'_{s}}{V_{s}}\times 100[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\frac{8.9925\times 10^{-5}}{1.0288\times 10^{-4}}\times 100 \\ &=8.41\%\simeq 87.5\% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 258 Results of a water sample analysis are as follows : (milliequivalent weight of [latex]CaCO_3[/latex]=50 mg/meq). Hardness of the water sample in mg/L as [latex]CaCO_3[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\text{Total hardness} =\left [ Mg^{2+} \right ]\times \frac{\text{eq. wt. of}\; \; CaCO_{3}}{\text{eq. wt. of}\; \; Mg^{+}}+\left [ Ca^{2+} \right ]\times \frac{\text{eq. wt. of}\; \; CaCO_{3}}{\text{eq. wt. of}\; \; Ca^{+}} [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\left ( 10\times \frac{50}{12.2} \right )+\left ( 55\times \frac{55}{20} \right ) \\ &= 178.48\simeq 179\; mg/l \end{aligned}[/latex] In addition to [latex]Ca^{2+}[/latex] and [latex]Mg^{2+}[/latex], other divalent metallic icons like [latex]Fe^{2+}[/latex], [latex]Mn^{2+}[/latex], [latex]Sr^{2+}[/latex], etc may also cause hardness but their presence is negligible in most of the waters. [latex]Na^{2+}[/latex] and [latex]K^{+}[/latex] do not contribute in hardness.

question: Question 266 The theoretical oxygen demand of a 0.001 mol/L glucose solution is
solution: [latex]1\: mol\: of\: glucose\rightarrow 6\: moles\: of\: O_{2}[/latex] [latex]0.001\: \frac{mol}{l}\: of\: glucose\rightarrow 0.006\: \frac{mol}{l}\: of\: O_{2}[/latex] Now, number of moles [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\frac{Wt\left ( g \right )}{Molecular\: Wt\left ( g \right )} \\ \therefore \; \; \text{Wt} &=0.006\times 32 \\ &=0.192\: g/l \\ &=192\; mg/l \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 273 A town has an existing horizontal flow sedimentation tank with an overflow rate of 17 [latex]m^3/day/m^2[/latex], and it is desirable to remove particles that have settling velocity of 0.1 mm/sec. Assuming the tank is an ideal sedimentation tank, the percentage of particles removal is approximately equal to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Overflow rate} &=17\; m^{3}/day/m^{2} \\ &=17\; m/day \\ &=\frac{17\times 1000}{24\times 60\times 60} \\ &=0.196\; mm/s \end{aligned}[/latex] Percentage particle removal [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\frac{0.1}{0.196}\times 100=50\% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 274 The [latex]Ca^{2+}[/latex] concentration and [latex]Mg^{2+}[/latex] concentration of a water sample are 160 mg/lit and 40 mg/lit as their ions respectively. The total hardness of this water sample in terms of [latex]CaCO_3[/latex] in mg/lit is approximately equal to
solution: Total hardness [latex]\begin{aligned} &=Ca^{+}\: mg/l\left ( \frac{50}{20} \right )+Mg^{+}\: mg/l\times \left ( \frac{50}{12} \right ) \\ &=160\times \frac{50}{20}+40\times \frac{50}{12} \\ &=566.67\: mg/l \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 275 If the [latex]BOD_{5,20}[/latex] of waste is 150 mg/L and the reaction rate constant (to the base 'e') at 20[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C is 0.35/day, the ultimate BOD in mg/L is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} k_{D} &=\frac{0.35}{2.3}=0.15/days \\ \text{Now}\; \;150 &=L\left [ 1-10^{-0.15\times 5} \right ]=0.822\: l \\ \therefore \; \; L &=\frac{150}{0.822}=181.54\: mg/l \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 276 The unit in which both sedimentation and digestion processes of sludge take place simultaneously is
solution: Imhoff tank contains two chamber, one is an upper chamber in which sedimentation takes place and another is lower chamber is which digestion of collected sludge takes place.
